description: Awesome wine bar on an up and coming, trendy street in the Dogpatch! Great selection of wine, awesome happy hour before 7PM on weekdays, and some nice flatbreads. Would definitely come back here.
author: Ethan B.

description:
Stopped by after a dinner in Dogpatch to enjoy some wine outside (outside seating is great). They've got couches inside and bar seating as well. Service was great!

-B
author: Brandon G.

description:
ARTICHOKE DIP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Chill small, place in dogpatch (mainly indoor seating with a few seats outside). It can get pretty busy after work, so I recommend coming early or super late. Good wine! And I love the artichoke dip!!!!!!!! So good!!!!!!!

ARTICHOKE DIP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Annie S.

description: Nice and cozy wine bar close to work! For happy hour (til 7pm), they had $17 half bottle carafes. Got one of the white wines cause it was hot. Great service, fairly small selection, but it's an intimate place to bring a date (or in my case, co workers!).
author: Michael K.

description:
We were across the way drinking when my group of three wanted to add another stop. We walked in on Friday, November 10th around 4:30pm. It wasn't too busy, so we managed to find a table by the restroom.

Happy Hour Half-Bottle Carafes till 7pm ($17 / Regular $21):
*Sauvignon Blanc, Kalex, "Alex K", Marlborough, New Zealand '15
*Tempranillo, ibuenas!, Vino De Espana '14

Apparently we arrived in time for HH, so a friend of mine just ordered the two wines to share. In general, they were drinkable table wines, but not really up my alley. I like my whites crisper and my reds more full bodied. Service was great though and our waiter was attentive. The wine bar was low key and we were able to chill and talk for the hour and a half we were here.

Good, bright wine bar to throw back a couple glasses of wine. If I were to find myself back, I think I'd skip the HH selections and go for the wines by the glass. Or just a straight bottle.
author: Elena N.

description:
Cool little place just south of the
Dog Patch.  The service was good, a lot of information available if you have questions.  They have a full and simple menu, good selection.  I order Pinot Noir, Hahn, Santa Lucia Highlands, California 2016, $34. Carafe, little pricey for the pour.  Nice spot to stop for a glass of wine, try a few different varieties, not an everyday watering hole.  Stop by, try a few different select wines and grab a bite.
author: David E.

description:
I came here with a coworker after for. Another long day where we just needed to wind down and drink some nice wine. She has been here before, while I have never been. This place was a pleasant surprise. I expected something on the classier since - mainly because it is a wine bar. That being said, while this place is classy, it does have some awesome paintings. There are Steve Urkel, Ninja Turtles and some police officer cartoon picture. Awesome! We got here closer to 6pm and it was just us and two other ladies. There are two separate rooms and somewhat divides the wine bar. Overall, the vibe is classy hipster, if that makes any sense.

The food is pretty limited. There are flatbread pizzas you can order, we ordered this artichoke dip and some other things that I don't really remember. The dip was solid, good stuff with leaks on top. 

Onto the main reason for going to this place. The wine. We both like Zinfandels and there was one on their menu. Very solid choice. I like the rusty oakey taste that goes along with Zins. The majority of the wines are from Sonoma County. Nice that Yield stays local. 

It did start getting busier around 7pm. From what I heard from the bartender there is a trivia night. We thought that would be cool to check out but we started getting hungry but that time and wanted more than just small bites. Otherwise, I think we would have stayed.

Great choice to go to after work.
author: Mark G.

description:
Nice and quaint wine bar in the dogpatch.  Couch, table, high table, or bar seating options.  Inside or on the sidewalk.  

Good selection of wines including happy hour specials.  Had the Alma Rosa Pinot Noir 2014 which was excellent.  

They also have small dishes such as Brussels sprouts, spicy nuts, or pizza.
author: Marcus K.

description: Very chill wine bar with simple decor and a couple of couches to lounge on while you sip your wine. There isn't an extensive list, but most of the wines here are very affordable and of good quality. Service is excellent, and you're never wanting for a seat. Unfortunately, if it is a rare, hot SF day, this place lacks air conditioning so just keep that in mind as you sip your lukewarm/warm wine.
author: Danny C.

description:
A stark store, with a cement floor and hardwood tables, gave it it a classic 90's vibe. 

While waiting for our reservations at aine, since there's no place to sit there, we wandered in for a glass of rose and she, bubbles. 

A kind staff took our orders for a Rosé of Prosecco, Pizzicato, "Paloma Rose," Veneto, Italy '16 and a Rosé of Limniona, Domaine Zafeirakis, Tyrnavos, Greece '16.  Neither of which meant anything to me. Add a dish of tasty olives. 

The check came to about $35. I'm sure the vintages were a fair price. For that price, we would have enjoyed it more if we were in The Redwood Room at The Clift.
author: David N.

description: Small cozy wine bar. The art work that hangs on the walls are very interesting lol. I came during happy hour on a Saturday. The half bottle carafes were $17, which I still thought was not cheap. The food was a dollar off, so $10. Ordered the Brussels sprouts and the smoked trout rillette. Didn't think it was worth $10 at all. Both were good but not worth the price, personally. Overall, this place is quite pricey but nice to just check out once.
author: Annie H.

description: Trivia night on Tuesday was a blast. Thanks to nick and his energetic, friendly announcing and programming! Also, yummy wines!
author: Laura R.

description: Came here for a happy hour glass of wine last Friday. The place is super sparsely decorated, the staff is friendly, and they have a good variety of wines on offer. Extra points for outdoor seating and generous pours!
author: Bailey D.

description:
The ambiance here is pretty rough. Met my sister here for a drink and was expecting good things given the 4.5 star rating; I was underwhelmed. The seating is not comfortable, it almost looks like a building under construction, it felt dirty. 

I will say the wine I had was very nice as were the olives we ordered, but they shouldn't be relying on their food and beverage alone.
author: Angela S.

description:
Great neighborhood wine bar. Nothing fancy simple, charming, rustic.. I
Dont come in expecting a huge list or food selection .. If your expectations are simple,  then you will love the local casual vibe. Im new to the area, checked this place out and fell in love. Come across trivia nigh Tues..  MUC is fantastic trivia challenging. Kick back have fun.
author: TJ S.

description:
Cute small industrial-like wine bar in Dogpatch.

We decided to pop in for happy hour on a random wednesday afternoon. We shared a carafe of a spanish verdejo that was forgettable, however their bites sounded appetizing, so we got the artichoke with fried leeks dip and it was AMAZING! 

Will be back to try some other wines and explore their small menu, but most likely not the wine they have offered for happy hour.
author: Roman V.

description:
Amazing trivia nights on Tuesdays! I suck at trivia, but I love going here anyway with friends, splitting a bottle of wine and some snacks, and racking our brains. They also have great vegan flatbread. 

Trivia starts around 8pm, but the place fills up before then. Try to show up at 7:30 to claim a spot for your group.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
I love you Yield. I love you love you love you love you. Even though I have never won Tuesday Night Trivia, much to my sadness. 

If you are looking for a place that makes you feel like home, this might be it. The people are incredibly friendly, and if you get there early enough to grab one of the comfy chairs, take it! The stools are...not so comfy after a bit. 

Could their wine menu use a bit of work? Yeh. Could they offer flights? Yeh. These are small things compared to the joy that coming here brings. Even if I do lose at trivia. Dang sports questions.
author: Danielle L.

description:
Came here for happy hour, which is from 4:30-7pm. Their HH deal is a carafe for $14, and $1 off menu items. We got the only red offered with the carafe and it was a medium bodied easy-drinker. Ha. We also got the cheese plate which was a-ok. Nothing fantastic. Nothing horrible. 

The location is convenient as its near the T muni line, and a few blocks from the 22nd street Caltrain. 

The decor is minimal, which I like, and the seating is ample. Service is friendly and responsive. I'll be back!
author: Evelyn M.

description:
SOPHISTICATED
(4 stars)

Sometimes you just need to tip the glass. 

SYRAH/GRENACHE/CARIGNAN/MOURVÈDRE, DOM, FERRET, RIBERE, "TRADITION", COTES DU RUSILLION, FRANCE '09 ($12) - earthy, figs, dry finish. I didn't think I'd like it but after trying it I ordered a glass of it. It's a nice creeper and the buzz will sneak up on you. 

COD SLIDERS ($8) - w/avocado, cilantro, sriracha aioli. This was good decent. Not sure how fresh the cod is as the taste of "fish" was kind of aggressive. Wish there was more cilantro to get an herb flavor. The sriracha aioli bright the perfect heat to the dish.

HOUSE-MARINATED OLIVES ($6) - this was delicious. I don't usually eat olives, ONLY when I'm drinking a really dirty martini or sipping wine. The evoo and roasted garlic was the perfect marinade for these olives. 

Will I be back? Why not. 

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
Attention all average Joe's and college students! 

This place is cool, and if you're grown and have your career under way, I can see how this place may be for you!

BUT if you're like myself, a broke college student then this place may not be for you. It is SUPER expensive. Flat bread pizzas at 14 each, that could not feed a small child, let alone a 6 foot 200 pound man like myself. Champagne bottles at 48 each, and we came with 10 people and we ended up paying 12 dollars each for 2 bottles which came out to about 2 glasses each.. Throw in some food orders and beer, and our bill ballooned to 200+... 

Side bar: the trivia night was fun. It felt like high school all over again, but with alcohol. But be prepared to not know half the questions if you're below he age of 25 lol most questions are pretty hard and without at least a team of 5 or a scholar who studied random facts then you will fail. But the experience was fun nonetheless. 

Back to the money.

If you're in the mood for drinking, and want to go somewhere, I'd suggest going to a bar with a happier hour that doesn't only take off 1DOLLAR! Weeee 1 dollar happy hour! 
Hardly a happy hour if you ask me..

Put it to you this way, you could spend 6 dollars for a bottle of champagne at Safeway that tasted the same, IF NOT BETTER and A large pizza from a pizza spot that's way better. 

Overall the night was fun, but next time I will definitely be going elsewhere to spend 200 dollars with my friends and get more bang for your buck.

But hey, if you got your career and want to spend 50 bucks on a few glasses of wine and a tasty, but small and thin pizza, you go ahead and be my guest! 

Thanks for reading!
author: John James M.

description:
When I was in my 20s, all I cared about was going to the hottest parties, getting sh*tfaced on adioses, and finding every opportunity to throw off my heels. YOLO! Ok, ok... more like ratchet. 

Now that I'm in my 30s, all I care about is wrinkle cream, flats, spanx, and sleep. 

Don't get me wrong, I still like going out at night and getting a happy buzz but I don't want to deal with parking, long lines, crowds, and running into my friend's younger sibling(s).

Me: "Oh hey, what are you doing here?"
Friend's younger sibling: "It's my homegirl's 21st birthday. What are YOU doing here?"

Me: "........"

Umm yah, so wine bars are now my BFF. 

Yield Wine Bar is perfect for someone like me; someone that still wants to enjoy the night life without getting all ratchet. Street parking is plentiful. Getting a seat isn't a problem before 10 pm (there's two communal tables for larger groups). And, the chances of getting sh*tfaced is minimal since they don't serve hard liquor. It's also a great date place as it's more intimate and the music isn't blaring so you can actually hold a conversation. 

Yield serves sustainable, organic and biodynamic (eco-friendly) wine. For wines by the glass, there were about 5 selections each for sparkling, white, and red wine ranging from $9-$13. Bottles ranged from mid $30s to low $80s. Happy hour is Monday - Friday, 4:30 pm - 7 pm and half bottle carafes are $12. 

They also have a rotating bar bite menu with vegan options (Hi John & Chel!). On the night that we went, there were nuts, olives, cheese, dips, and flatbreads on the menu ($6-$13). Kitchen closes at 10 pm. 

I had a glass of the sparkling rose and a chardonnay that I wasn't too crazy about but that's just me as I prefer Italian or French wines. The food and service more than made up for it though. 
 
My gf and I shared the grilled brussel sprouts ($6), cod sliders (2 for $8), and the Parisian flatbread ($13) for a late dinner. The cod sliders are a must order. A pan-fried cod patty topped with a creamy sriracha aioli, buttery avocados, and sandwiched between a pillowy Hawaiian bun. I love sweet and salty combos so the Parisian flatbread was an easy choice as it was topped with brie, apples, and caramelized onions: http://bit.ly/1mYxUOp. The flatbread had a nice crunch with great flavors from the ménage a trois of ingredients but the apples could have been sliced thinner as it had more of a mushy texture.

We spent over 3 hours at Yield and we never felt rushed. Our waitress was an absolute sweetheart and kept checking in with us to make sure everything was ok. 

Definitely adding Yield to my weekend rotation as they close at midnight which gives me enough time to go home to catch an episode of Cheaters. Mmmm, that Clark Gable, THE III; Grade A douche but yummy nonetheless.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Went here for trivia on Tuesday with a group of 6. Had a great time and loved the happy hour deals!
author: Allie L.

description:
Pretty cute place in the Dogpatch/Potrero area.
A decent selection of wines and VEGGIE-FRIENDLY food! yay!
Plenty of parking around
Right by the MUNI line
Owner/bartender is friendly and attends to the guests well, checks in regularly but not too frequently.
Plenty of seating area - at the bar, high tables, some nice sofas/couch kinda seating too.
author: Kinjal S.

description:
This Dogpatch gem features delicious and sustainably sourced wines. The selection changes with the season, and you can't go wrong with anything from the menu. If you're uncertain about which to choose, simply ask someone working there what types of flavors you like best, and they'll point you in the right direction.

The neighborhood is quiet--"up and coming" as many have said, and the venue is small, intimate, and cozy. The menu boasts the occasional rotation of vegan options, making it more hospitable to the meat and dairy challenged. It does tend to be on the pricey side (hence four stars instead of five), but the happy hour is excellent. And don't miss Wednesday trivia night.

Among my favorite memories include meeting the owner's adorable dog, and having the same man pulling me over several times to tell me he liked my jacket. In his drunken stupor he'd forgotten every previous time. Yield gives you a good buzz without an awful hangover the next day.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I'm not a big wine guy, but Yield is an excellent wine bar. How do I judge a wine bar without being a wine aficionado? It's simple:
- The bartender is super attentive and friendly
- The menu is diverse in both style and price
- The venue is real trendy yet chill
- Samples and half glasses are available for the neophyte in all of us

I'll definitely return if I'm in the area.
author: Casey S.

description:
This cute wine bar doesn't seem like much from the outside but once you step inside, wonderful cozy ambience for a medium sized group.

I came here with coworkers to celebrate the end of a phase of our project. I was very pleased with the small plates that we shared and the wine paired nicely. 

We shared one of the preset menus of appetizers (I don't recall all of them but a few were quite good that they stood out in my mind.) The salted Brussels sprouts were delicious, and the aioli sauce that came with the dish added a creamy finish that was just perfect. One of my coworkers loved the artichoke dip so much that we ordered another plate. The variety of pizza plates appealed to all of us. My personal favorite was the pesto flatbread. The smoked trout and lightly toasted bread was also a group pleaser. 

Overall, I'll definitely be back! Ambience, food, service--excellent.
author: Kristi L.

description: Warm and pleasant vibe! Date appetizer was excellent!  Fresh bread and dip was awesome!
author: Raja K.

description: The food was mediocre.  We ordered Brussel sprouts for HH. It was way to sour.  The waiter broke a bunch of wine glasses in front of us.  The best part of this whole experience, oh wait there wasn't any.
author: Seema S.

description: Simple, to the point wine bar with not a lot of frills. Friendly and attentive service.
author: Maggie S.

description:
Pros:
- fairly wide range of wines available
- wines from all the continents
- cool & calm interior = great for talking
- intimate setting (there are cushy seats good for dates)
- really attentive, friendly staff

Cons:
- kind of pricey, but I think it's worth it
- not in an extremely convenient location

Bottom line: I've had some good wine and talks here. If you're in the neighborhood, you should stop by. I'll be back.
author: Jiann M.

description: Within 3 minutes the bartender had us laughing. Always an awesome sign. I live for all things organic- wine included. Love the vegan flatbread option (although the menu had a ton of great non-vegan options). Awesome spot to relax with friends!
author: Sara L.

description: A comfortable and welcoming atmosphere. The staff is always willing to take the extra time to meet your needs. An excellent selection of wines, and the best damned artichoke dip this side of the Bay Bridge.
author: Katie P.

description: Super good wine and just a really cool spot. Easy place to bring friends and family. Really easy to get to cause it's on 3rd street and awesome. Just had the artichoke dip and it was amazing. Staff is super knowledgeable about the wine and it's just such a. Good spot to come and chill. Come here, enjoy company and wine and have fun. :) :)
author: Michelle P.

description:
***************************** 1,033  *******************************

        It was a random night when my friend and I came here, it was late and we just wanted some wine to warm us up. I Yelped it and here, Yield Wine Bar still opens till midnight. 

     Cute little wine bar, love the warm so far, seductive lighting, no one was here since it was a Thursday night. We glad to get the place for ourselves.  They opened Yield in 2006, I bet there was nothing going on here then, and they survive all these years, now the Dogpatch has become a bonafide micro-hood, a destination for food, wine, even ice cream, and always happening every weekend here. 

    The wine list was simple, less than 15 by the glass, and less than 30 bottles selection, well-priced, and new and old world wines, which I love. Nic was at the bar, he was so gracious to welcome us in. I then apologized to come in late and told him, we would leave on time, which we did at midnight.

    Dauvergne Ranvier Chateaunuef-du-pape 2010 was what I ordered, being in the business, I know what I like, even my friend wanted a lesser cost bottle. I feel that if I had to keep Nic opened for us, might as well order the nicest bottle they had to offer. 

    It was good, it was fun, and we finished the bottle, and we left happy. Thank you Nic for the hospitality. It made such a different for the evening for us. I can't wait to come back soon and try the food!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
When I lived in the neighborhood this was a cool place to have some small plates and drink some good wine. The atmosphere was upbeat and the lighting was good, a rare find at the time in the dogpatch.

The location is easy to park, walk, or take the light rail on 3rd Street. Good place to meet friends or to settle in for a few hours.
author: Greg O.

description: So I really like coming here on my day off, Monday. The bartenders (wine peeps) are great, knowledgable and very nice. I usually show up before 5 on a Monday and watch this place fill up, but not get cray, by 630. They also have beer and cider for the non-wine drinkers. The olives are great as well as my favorite, the Smoked Trout Rillette. Grant and Nick at the bar are great!
author: Mackenzie K.

description:
It's got 300 plus reviews so you know people love this place.  Here's why I did:
- They have good food, and the kitchen's open late too.  Get the sliders!
- And the Rillette: smoked trout magic, do it.
- I'm not a wine expert but we really liked the ones called (on our receipt): "Spice Route Pinotage" and "Chocalan Carmenere."  

We also had the dates and the "Californian Flatbread" which were both just OK.

Service here is legendarily friendly, enthusiastic, and recommendation loaded.  Don't be shy here; ask the expert running the place!
author: Aaron M.

description:
I'm a fan! Granted, we made our Yield debut on the Saturday night of Outside Lands, so the entire city had made their way to GG Park, not the Dogpatch. Needless to say, we were the only folks there, but I kinda liked it! 

Wine was tasty, well-priced, and pours were more than generous. Two thumbs way up. Also learned they do trivia(!) Hoping to make it back sooner than later.
author: Brianna M.

description:
A nice chill yet classy vibe. Walk by it every day on my commute and finally met up with a friend here on a Tuesday night. Which happens to be trivia night - we didn't partake but got to listen to the (extremely difficult) questions and see the intellectual crowd squirm with the challenge.

The service was super friendly. The guys at the bar were all smiles, totally willing to give recs and knew the menu well - my water was always filled and overall, I just had a fun time.

* Torrontes, Tarantas, $8 - was recommended this when I said I like something sweeter and lighter. This did fit the description but was a little on the dry side - still pleasant to drink, however.

* Porto, Quinta de la Rosa - my buddy picked this one on a whim and it ended up being delicious. A nice full-bodied and yet sweet port. Delicious.
author: Ziyan C.

description: I have been here before and has a decent experience. This review is for the current bartender. We had to call him over because he was too busy texting to take our order. We ordered two glasses of wine and a pizza. 15 minutes later our pizza was no where to be found, but bartender was busy talking to his friend and texting. When we asked about the pizza and the bartender realized his mistake he didn't offer us a way to make it up, but rather made excuses - "I thought the order went through."  We promptly closed out our tab and went to Gilberth's across the street.
author: Sarah T.

description:
adorable little wine bar in dogpatch that has trivia on tuesday nights. $14 happy hour half carafes are a great deal until you order 6 and are reevaluating your life on wednesday morning. next tuesday Team Hillary's SideBerns are comin' at ya.

THOSE DATES THOUGH.
author: Reyana F.

description:
This is one of my favorite wine bars to go to in SF. There's definitely wine bars where you go and you're thinking "what the...is this even a bar? Where's the wine?" But rest assured, this one is not one of them. 

Yield Wine Bar has that swag that not many wine bars have. the seating is pretty ample for the a small place. There are essentially two seating areas and a bench at the bar where you can talk to the bartender. It's pretty awesome if you are with a group or on a date. Either one works! If you are just trying to learn about wine as well, I would highly suggest sitting at the bar. The employees here are very knowledgable and they even give you samples if you ask for it. Overall I had an awesome time.
author: Nathan L.

description: Had a team happy hour today. Awesome place and service. Pesta pizza is good. Chris is awesome service
author: Santosh M.

description:
Dogpatch is always referred to as "Up and Coming" because of great places like Yield. 

I'll keep this short n' sweet. Yield has the ambiance that you want in a wine bar. Cool, classy, but not ostentatious. The staff was friendly and knowledgeable, the wine (this is my friends POV) was a diverse range in both price and origin. 

We ordered the stuffed figs (absolutely amazing, 100% you should order them) and the brussel sprouts. I dinged this place a star because the sprouts were $9 and way, way too lemony. My advice? Just order two plates of the fits.
author: Jake B.

description: Solid 3 stars, cozy neighborhood hangout, but nothing to write home about menu-wise.  Trivia Night on Tuesday nights is a good time if you are friends with trivia nerds and want to win a percentage off of your bill.  The owner is friendly and energetic.  The server wasn't attentive or personable, and several times, our table tried to flag him down and he acknowledged us, but then kept forgetting to come over to take our order for drinks or snacks.
author: Kari L.

description: Thank goodness the wine is better than the furniture.  The environment is lacking, but the wine is pretty good.  For sure,  the ambiance,  decor,  and furnishing lacked any style and appeared to be aged and weathered.  It was a turn off,  upon walking in, but glad we stayed.  The Malbec was good.
author: N F.

description: Stopped by on my way home one day. Wanted a quiet spot to hang out at and this was perfect. Paid  $14 for half bottle on HH pricing and for the peace and quiet it was worth it. New to SF so exploring different places. Totally worth it, if you like wine
author: Katherine R.

description: Absolutely excellent experience. Wonderful wine selection by the glass - definitely try the cabs! Very nice small bites, energy was really good, and the service was quite outstanding. Will definitely go back!
author: Irina B.

description: Nice space, excellent wine selection.  my friend and I had a few glasses of wine, a pizza, and the nuts.  Wine & food was good, service was great.
author: melissa g.

description:
Great neighborhood spot. Service is as good as it gets and I've never had a glass of wine here I disliked. Food options are delicious and it's rarely crowded.

Note that the hours are wrong on Yelp as of this review. They are open 3-11pm Monday through Saturday, closed Sunday.
author: Rob A.

description:
I have been to Yield many times and usually really enjoyed it.  I was actually there the day it opened and was one of their first customers.  Their food is very good, and the atmosphere is nice. 

They no longer take reservations for groups, so the new system is that you show up and wait for people to vacate tables.  We did that and told the waitress that we had a large group, she agreed that we should just keep our eyes open.  They also had a couple of other groups, so it was really packed.  The first problem is that there were only two people working on a Friday night.  

We got one table with no problem.  When a second table next to us opened up, someone from my group asked if it was ours and the waitress told him yes.  That's when it got weird, really weird.  Our group started to sit at the table and she came running over saying that the table was "reserved for the general public", this was just minutes after she had given it to us.  We asked why we were not considered a part of the "general public", why the time we had waited didn't count, and why she had given us the table only to take it away.  She never gave a rational response, just the same general public comment.  At this point more of our group was showing up and it was getting packed in our little corner.

About a half an hour later we were able to get another table, but she came over and kicked us out of that table stating that we could only have one table per group.  The table we had sat 8, the one we were trying to add sat 2, we had a gradually enlarging group that ended up being 30+ people.  We would have been fine if she had let us expand as tables vacated, but she insisted that we we all share that first table even though we were ordering food and drinks.  We had to eat standing up.  All night she was extremely rude to us and pushed past people.  I'm sure it wasn't that fun for the people next to us either.  

She also insisted that all of us share one tab.  A few people managed to trick her and order from the bar, but she "caught" them and made them add on to our tab.  As you can imagine that was fun for me to untangle.    

This woman continued to be incredibly rude to us all evening, up until the check came.  This lunatic actually thought she'd be getting a tip.  I did give the other guy a small tip because while he was aloof, he didn't actually yell at us.    

This was the absolute worst service I've had anywhere, ever.  This woman went out of her way to be rude to us to the point that everyone kept asking what had happened.
author: Tonie C.

description: Cute little spot in the dog patch. We got there at the end of Trivia night and so I completely understand the bad service BUT I do not like that our $14 pizza (small/tiny.. The size of my tiny hand) came to us cold. On top of that we got our food when everyone was leaving so it's I expected the that the service would get better. It didn't... We asked for some cheese and red pepper flakes and the guy said that there was enough cheese on the pizza LOL why couldn't he just say "we don't have any cheese sorry" I asked for an extra plate... We got it when we were already finished. By the time we asked for our check we were the only customers there and we had to ask twice for it and just ended up walking up to the register. I'm so sick of the customer service in SF. The food is not that good yet hella stupid expensive and than we get treated like crap for asking for a thing or two.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I could wax poetic about this place endlessly. It is my new favorite thing in San Francisco, pretty much.

My first experience here was with parentals in tow. We were lucky enough to hit happy hour specials, and much wine was shared all around. The happy hour carafe is a good deal, and the wine is actually decent wine. Most happy hour carafe deals are pretty low quality wine, but not at Yield! We shared several dishes, of which the brussels sprouts were definitely a real standout.

I returned recently and with glee. I settled in to do some work, and Francesca was very fast with bringing me water and offering if I needed wifi password information. Once I was joined, we got a couple glasses of wine and shared some food. Once again, awesome brussels, along with a roasted butternut flatbread. Everything was absolutely delicious. It's so refreshing to go somewhere that is wine focused but doesn't insist that every pairing be meat or cheese. The veg options here are just so good, and they're reasonably priced. At happy hour, they become a downright bargain.

The best part of the Yield experience, though, is Nic, your friendly wine-slinger. He is energetic, friendly, and seems to be having a fantastic time every time he is at work. He zips between parties, having conversation with everyone, keeping everyone's glasses full, and delivering food seamlessly. He knows his wine, and will happily give recommendations, or let you make your own way. He is so fun, and he makes you feel like he is just so excited/happy that you're there. It's hard to be in anything other than a great mood when you're being taken care of by Nic.

Ultimately, the real problem with this place is that it's in the Dogpatch. I almost want to live there just so I can spend all my free time and money at Yield. But I'd settle for someone opening a swanky wine bar on my block in the Tenderloin. Anyone? Please? Till then, I guess I'll just keep commuting to Yield.
author: Vivienne P.

description: Second time I come. I am starting to develop a fondness for this place. Nothing too fancy or big, but a great spot in Dogpatch to sit back and enjoy a nice glass of wine (or two) in good company, with good music, good food, and a nice wine selection and food to try.
author: Manny H.

description:
Yield used to be my favorite wine bar.  I brought everyone I could there to enjoy the great selection of organic wines in a casual, comfortable environment.  The small bites were great for a light dinner or as an appetizer for dinner elsewhere.  The staff was friendly and helpful.

Much of that has changed.  The past three times I've visited there was only one waiter/waitress who was absolutely frantic ... despite not being that crowded.

Once I came there with a group of 6 people, and just after we were served our first glass, we were asked to move to a different table for a group of 10 people that was coming in (even though there are no reservations offered).  We felt it was a little rude but still complied.  We playfully asked if we could get a free glass for our troubles and were told absolutely not.  We would have been happy with nothing if the waiter had returned the joke or at least been courteous with us.

Another time I came in with a date who asked if she could taste two different wines.  We were told only one taste per customer is permitted.  We countered that one can't make a choice from only one option.  Rather than simply give us a small taste (like every other wine bar in existence) or say "sorry but I'm really not allowed" the response was a flat "Only one taste per customer."

Yield went from someplace I enjoyed brining my friends and coworkers to, a place where the staff recognized me and were happy to see me, to a place where the waitstaff are overworked and rude and where management doesn't seem to understand that giving $1 worth of wine to someone who will pay $50 on a bottle is a good investment.
author: Garth W.

description:
Awesome, awesome place! Yield Wine Bar is a little cute place in the Dogpatch, very cozy and modern-ish. The owner? Nick and the event organizer Chris are absolutely fantastic. My bridesmaids held an engagement party for me there this past weekend. I'm a big fan of wine and their selections were great!

I unfortunately didn't get to try all the wines I wanted to, just had me a little too much glasses of the rose prosseco (which I have to say is amazing)! 

Just wanted to thank the staff for being really accommodating, always checking up on us and being a pleasure to work with. Thanks Yield!
author: Angela K.

description: This is a cozy little place to enjoy a nice glass of wine. There is a great selection and the staff is friendly and attentive. My husband and I enjoy coming here for a casual date night or to meet up with groups of friends. We have always had a fantastic experience here.
author: K J.

description: Great place!  Loved the wine selection and the ambiance was very relaxing.  The cheese, fruit plate was lovely. Great service, pleasant host and great music. Would definitely come back.
author: Melissa O.

description:
Two years later... still great.  Did anything change?  Yes.

1. It's become more packed.  Business is good!

2. A lot more women.  In fact, there were probably 20 women and 5 men when we went last night.  The ratio was so overwhelming that I joked to my boyfriend "if and when you become single again, you should come here to meet people!".
author: Kristen S.

description: Similar to Pause (their other location in SOMA). Love the vibe and atmosphere. Great wine selection.
author: Judy L.

description: Cozy cute perfectly lit and comfortable neighborhoody, just busy enough, busy great happy hour by the carafe, and attentive service - ARTICHOKE DIP TO DIE FOR.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Cute little wine bar in Dogpatch? Really? 

'Tis true. There's a great selection of crisp whites and deep reds at Yield, and the pub trivia nights are a lot of fun. (But come early.) The seating here seems a bit more apt for large groups, so while my team of two lucked out with seats, we were a bit mashed between two groups trying to talk over the trivia host. (Seriously? Rude.) 

If you like a great glass and you're in the Dogpatch, Yield makes for an excellent choice.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I finally know what and where the Dogpatch is...jeezzzz.

Well, after a visit to the Museum of Craft and Design, my friend and I decided it's still an early night, why not a drink?  It so happen that the bar next door does not serve food, so we venture our way to Yield.

Good variety of white and reds to choose from.  The (only) guy at the bar helped me with my wine choice.  I'm glad I told him what I wanted and he gave me his recommendation.  For appetizers we ordered, olives (a must!), stuffed dates and the sheep cheese.  We couldn't have made better selections.

Small cozy place.  Busy on a Thursday night.  We enjoyed our wine and food and was impressed at how attentive the bartender was inspite of the fact that it's only him and another guy in the kitchen manning the place.
author: Pam S.

description: We went here for Tuesday trivia night to celebrate my birthday. Young crowd, but no one made us 50-somethings feel awkward. Terrific offerings and happy hour deals. The cod sliders and brussels sprouts are amazing. Really friendly service. Can't speak to parking because we took Lyft. And guess what? We placed second and got 20% off our bar bill!
author: Susan K.

description:
Another little Dog Patch Gem, this place would be great if it weren't for the seating. There are a lot of stools with low tables and it's very uncomfortable for anyone of average height.

I saw a review on here from someone who brought 30+ people and was miffed they couldn't get a table or rearrange the whole place to their liking. The place has got about 6 tables/ seating areas total. Not sure where else they're going where a group of that size can just filter in and expand to any table they please, but if you don't come in with that sense of entitlement and a group of 6-8, you'll be fine.

But if those stars align and it doesn't get too packed, it's a nice little place. The wine selection is on par/ better than joints of the same size and their food is very good. Skip the cheese board and go for the flatbreads and the artichoke dip.
author: Brandon K.

description:
I'll have to come back for happy hour, and I'll have to try the food to really get a better sense of the place. 

As it stands, their wine selection is pretty limited and tends to be on the pricier side if you're drinking by the glass. I mean, organic/biodynamic wines and all that, there just aren't that many of them. And the ones I've tried are...drinkable, but not exactly amazing for the price.

That said, I'm looking forward to being more impressed on my second visit.
author: Connor Skye R.

description:
Lovely little spot with great wine. 

Food:
-Less salt please. Less salt, less salt. Less salt on the flat bread, and the fries, and everything else. Your food is too salty.
-Less oil please. Lee oil on the brussels sprouts, and everything else

Service:
- The guy who works in the evenings is great, the gal is on it when it comes to service, but a bit on the fake side. Tone it down lady and just be a bit more real.

The room on the right side is unbelievably loud; it's a like a hollowed out wooden cavern, every conversation and laugh bounces of all walls. Would help the ambience if the sound could be dampened.
author: Stanley D.

description: I used to live in the neighbourhood, a super casual and cozy place. Great tapas. Cool and knowledgable staff.
author: Shell J.

description:
I visited Yield again last night after a long hiatus, and as it happens I stopped in at Pause (their new location on Market St) this same week. Service remains top notch, if a little over-friendly. 

A couple of things have gone downhill though - first of all, the wine glasses! What is with the weird tulip-shaped glasses??? Someone must have convinced them that this unconventional shape was a good idea but I think it's a big mistake. The tulip lets all the aroma out and makes me feel like I'm drinking cheap wine. 

Second - the wine selection has gotten slimmer. Still some good choices, but only 5 reds by the glass is a little limiting for a wine bar. 

Third - the red wine needs to be temperature controlled. It was served slightly warm on both occasions. 

Invest in some real glasses, guys!
author: Bowen D.

description:
I notice a few reviews where large groups have been treated rudely by staff at Yield. I've worked in the service industry and large groups are sometimes hard to manage, so I normally take such reviews with a grain of salt.  But my recent experience at Yield, with a party of three, was so strange and disappointing, I decided to add my experience to the bad reviews.

I've been to Yield about 4 or 5 times and always had excellent to pretty good service. That's also how my evening started out, securing a spot and a couple of glasses of wine and some snacks. The weirdness happened when we were joined by a third person after about 45 minutes. The wait staff seemed to be actively ignoring us for about 15 minutes. Then one of us went to the bar and both of the staff refused to acknowledge him. Finally, when another one of our party approached the woman who had been serving us very pleasantly so far and asked her politely, "when you have a moment, we'd like to order some more wine + food..." the woman turned and said flatly, "it'll be a while".

We were really shocked and unsure of what just happened.  We decided to leave immediately.  When I paid the bill, the other staff member didn't seem surprised we were leaving so soon and didn't ask how our evening was going or make any kind of conversation at all.

It seems quite in line with what the other low reviewers have said here. We were a small, quiet group and are always respectful of servers' time - were we not drinking enough?  I'm so disappointed because I have really enjoyed Yield in the past, but this experience has completely turned me off and makes me wonder what is going on.
author: Megan G.

description: Great place...perfect ambiance to just chill after a long day and great selection on your 'less than mainstream' wines.  Apps were amazing...I'd redo the Cod Sliders.
author: Kenneth J.

description:
A nice little place (and I do mean little) in the remote area that is the Dogpatch, this was the location for a lovely little engagement celebration for one of my best friends and her fiancé. While the main area located by the front counter/bar looked super comfy with sofas and soft chairs with pillows (which, by the end of the three-hour shindig, were looking extremely enticing considering how loudly my knees were screaming in pain from all of the standing), the adjoining area was almost all standing room with limited stool seating. 

Beyond that, the selection of wines was quite nice. The whites were very enjoyable, and the reds that I tried (the first pinot noir on the list and the blend from Field Recordings) were fantastic. The serving sizes were on the generous side, which considering the pricier nature of this place is definitely a good thing. 

The service was absolutely great. While the woman that was working that night was more on the quiet side, she was still courteous and took care of grabbing empty glasses before gravity did. The man working that night  was extremely friendly and charismatic, attentive, and right on top of things. Great service!

As more people poured in for the party, the place got louder and louder. Our area was pretty much all walls and concrete, so our voices carried even a bit too well, eventually getting to the point where we had to more or less shout to speak to someone directly next to us. Not particularly anyone's fault; just makes this place not great for larger/louder parties, haha. 

This was a very nice place that I hope to come back to sometime in the future. Hopefully then I'll be able to try those cod sliders that looked and smelled so damn amazing!
author: Andrew C.

description: I was shocked by how much I liked this wine bar, given that we inadvertently stumbled into the Tues happy hour. We were surprised at how crowded it was relatively early on a week night, but we soon realized it was for trivia. We initially considered heading out, but decided to stay, which was a great choice. I don't always like trivia nights but this one was great, mainly due, I think, to Nick's amazing, friendly hosting & mc'ing. Also, the kept bringing out food and wine during the trivia. I enjoyed the wine - my only misgivings were the somewhat cramped seating areas, which weren't tremendously comfortable lounging around, and that the food was pretty light - fine for snacking but not much to stand up to all the wine you may be having!
author: Lisa K.

description:
A little small for my taste but the owners have done a great service to this quiet community.
Great selection of wine!!!
author: Peter B.

description:
Highly recommended!!  Wish I lived in the neighborhood so I could become a "regular".  At least glad I have friends who live in the neighborhood.  

From the moment I walked through the door, I was greeted and told to sit where ever I liked.  The bartender then came over and finished clearing a table at the window that she thought was a better place.  When I pulled out my iPad, she told me the wifi password and came back to make sure it worked alright.

The wine selection is very nice and the staff is quite familiar and knowledgeable.  I was interested in the Happy Hour red wine from Chile.  I usually stay away from Happy Hour wines - not always very good.  The bartender spoke highly of the wine...and it was very good, especially for $15 for a half bottle.

I have had some food items here in the past...always good and some of the items are creative.

If you are in the area or even want to check out the dogpatch neighborhood, venture out here.
author: Ryan O.

description: Organic and sustainable wine!  Plus, a happy hour (carafe of Carmenere for $12 = about 3 glasses, white wine too, Carmenere was lovely though).  Plus, they have food too!  Props to the guy who took care of us because we were a pretty big party who were thirsty, hungry, loud on a early Friday evening.  If I am out in this area, I would definitely go back, and if anyone needs a recommendation for a quaint wine bar with lovely wine, food and service - this is your place!
author: Maile N.

description:
I don't know whether it's the feel of the restaurant that you get or the service that you get that makes you love this place more, but I swear, if I lived in SF I'd probably make this my home away from home. The bartender is very knowledge about the wines that they do serve by the glass, from the flavor profiles to the regions the grapes are grown in and why they produce different flavors in the grapes. It's awesome just being able to hear him describe the wines. He also makes you feel right at home and is super friendly. 

If you love rose's I would highly recommend the rose of malbec. My date and I both loved this one. The red mablec is also really good. We also ordered a fried oyster mushroom appetizer. It's like the calamari of mushrooms. Granted it was kind of over salted, but it was still perfectly fried with the outside being really crisp and the inside moist and tender. I will be coming back soon!
author: Grace C.

description:
awesom staff, awesome wine, awesome vegan pizza! Go there on Thuesday for "Trivia", so much fun.
A place, where you HAVE to go, when in SF!
author: Hannah M.

description:
Strip away the pretensiousness of most wine bars, simplify the wine menu to a few selections of each varietal, pair with some tasty noshable & sensibly priced food, hire an effervescent and friendly wait staff and sommeliers, then hide all of it away in a cozy little two-room establishment small enough to miss if you don't know its there?

Seems to be the formula to success.

While waiting for a dinner reservation at nearby Piccino (we'd eventually end up at Serpentine across the street instead), our group of 6 decided to bide our time with drinks and small bites here. Thankfully the people I was with were familiar (*cough*regulars!*ahem*) at this establishment, otherwise I would have walked right past it. The place is quaintly small.

Walking in, your soon met by friendly staff as well as passing glances from people seated on sofas and ottomans around low tables in the first/front room. It very much has a cozy aire of walking into someone's home. An eclectic music selection plays in the background and overhead, conversations are kept at a considerate volume. To the right is another area more outfitted like a bar with high tables and stools. Canvases of artwork adorn the walls in both rooms and soft candlight throughout keeps the ambiance intimate. 

Though we unfortunatly missed the lobster mac-n-cheese for the evening, we partook in some other light eats to pass the time. Grilled flatbread and french fries... [ http://dl.dropbox.com/u/39275848/Menus/yieldwinelist.pdf ] Rather, while the ladies whetted their appetites, I explored my lush-y side and had three glasses of wine in our short time there. The '06 Abbaye de Tholomies Syrah/Grenache/Mouvedre and the '07 Velocity Malbec/Cabernet were both remarkable.

The staff is energetic and high-spirited, checking in with parties/table fairly often; waters were constantly filled, empty glasses taken, new pours prompted, etc. We were eagerly ushered to a larger, more accomodating table when our party got bigger. Excellent example of attention to customer service.

It's immediately become one of my favorite places to go to when visiting friends in the City.
_____________________________
It's a good thing I don't reside nearby.
At the bottom of the menu is the wi-fi passkey - I'd be "working" from here all the time.
author: Mikey U.

description: Beautiful lounge. It's the perfect place to unwind after dinner, sit by the fire, chat with the locals, relax on the couch. It's the perfect living room coziness. Thanks Nic for the great experience. He knows his wines and was very helpful in selecting recommendations. Can't wait til brunch kicks off.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Cozy and intimate...and friendly service...just the way a wine bar should be. 
Places like this makes me want to further explore the little gems hidden throughout our wonderful city!
author: Mimi T.

description: this is a cute place w/ cheap wine if you come during happy hour.  the food menu looked really good but i was already going to dinner, so i didn't get to try.  i will have to come again next time.  the decor could probably use some freshening up though.  i felt like i was going into a college friend's living room.
author: Helen T.

description:
Here's a very relaxing spot in Dogpatch.  Comfy seating and ambience.  Nice if concise wine list, some beer choices for the outlier male element (thanks!) and pub items that make me think of Seattle's enlightened gastro pub approach.  Who wouldn't appreciate a bite with their  beverage of choice?  We tried the cauliflower appetizer - it was succulent and flavorful with just the right salt + citrus note.  Could have eaten a whole dinner of that!  Soon Yield will be featuring a "pescaterian" popup brunch... will have to try that!  Reservations are possible for parties of eight or more.

Did I mention that pricing is very fair?  Yield to the temptation and try it!
author: Bob K.

description:
A nice little organic wine bar in the Dogpatch.

The T line runs right by it making it an easy spot to get to.

I have never had a wine there that i have even seen anywhere else.  They take pride in selling organic wines that are pretty dilicous.

My only comlaint is that it is a bit small and at times they are out of cheeses, chocolates and other desserts.  

Don't let it deter you from trying some of their wonderful wines but don't hold your breat if you are looking to get a bite to eat....
author: Reggie A.

description:
$20 for a Prix Fixe Vegetarian brunch with a rdiculous amount of ridiculously good vegetarian tapas and a Mimosa: the dream! This + terrasse + people watching + the sun = heaven!
People: Just do it!
author: virginie d.

description: Crazy for any wine bar: this place has great indoor and outdoor seating and a very good selection of wines. Very low key, quiet, and great for conversations. Will be coming back in no time.
author: Ana J.

description:
Just posting again to acknowledge the fantastic experience of trivia night.
Nic, the cute little guy with the big voice shouts the questions out to a packed crowd.
author: Gary N.

description:
Sorry to be a hater, but I'm a wine snob.  Been to ones that do it right, so just some advice.  You need more options.  The menu is way too limited, and needs more variety.  I think you should always have 3-4 wines of each varietal, not just strictly one of each type.  Should offer flights, because I can tell you, any wine fanatics go goo goo ga ga for that stuff.  Offer crackers to every guest, to help clean their palate.  And pricing, was a bit much, but its SF.  Perhaps that's normal.  The menu was decent.  Had a nice selection, but I guess its a small place so you can only do so much.  It also seemed a little too quiet, and needed something to add to the atmosphere.  Perhaps some indie alternative music or more wall art?  Feel like I'm being a consultant now, sorry.

Well, i've been to one wine bar that told me that they bought some of their stuff thru Grocery Outlet.  So if you serve your nice stuff, cool, but consider adding some budget stuff in there too.  Won't hit your pocket too hard, and since your the expert, find some that are good and mark it up to serve to us.  Bam, you got yourself more fans.  Just saying.
author: Janice F.

description:
The place was pretty packed tonight especially for a small place, but their servers were constantly going around collecting glasses and plates and making sure everyone was happy.

Someone actually took my plate mistakenly with one last delicious chocolate chip, dried cherry cookies and they replaced it with two!  Thank you!

I can't attest to any other foods, but I ordered two glasses of the Z-Cuvee Cab Franc meritage...very full-bodied and delicious!  I'm looking for it in the store!

Apparently, there was a Spanish flamenco dance performance tonight and they were fabulous!  I'll definitely remember to stop by any time I'm in the area!
author: Coy T.

description: Really cute little bar, great food and really friendly staff!
author: Tiffany R.

description:
It's just this simple: come in, drink wine, have snacks, be merry!
Time an time again, I have had wonderful experiences at yield. We come in, one of the cheerful folks greets us, seats us and promptly brings us water and the menu. We often share a happy hour carafe (steal!) or get a few glasses. The staff always know the perfect description of the wines so we can make an informed decision or try something new. The snacks are small plates that pack a big punch. You will likely try 2 or 3 and will love them all!
author: lmej p.

description:
So who hangs out in the dogpatch anyways? My friend and I were thinking about meeting up so we decided to venture out of our typical FiDi happy hour choices and check out Yield. 

Definitely a different crowd. So who hangs out in the dogpatch? Well, on that particular Thursday evening after work it was mostly old lesbians and one large table of asians. 

As for the wine...pretty awesome wine list. Most wines are made from biodynamic grapes.  They have some great options. The happy hour special is a $10 carafe of either red or white wine of the day.  Our choices that day were a Cab from Contra Costa County or a Sauvignon Blanc from Argentina.
author: Debbie C.

description:
I was here last Saturday. "Great, humble people serving great wines".

tried:

i) Carmenere with salmon (Amazing)
ii) Plavac Mali with stuffed dates (Amazing) (this wine comes from a winery based in croatia along the coast of Adriatic sea.
iii) After dinner wine : Vin santo 2002, this is a greek wine, had this wine with cod sliders.

price is reasonable for the quality of wine that's sold here.

i'm going to stop by tomorrow for their happy hours.
author: lokesh y.

description: This is one of the reviews where I talk about a place I was dragged into because of work.  Anyhow Mr. RV, who is no longer with the company, and is or was friends with the owner of the place, convinced our traveling work fellows to come here.  A group of about 14 of us came to discuss the logistics of the UCSF Mission Bay Project. Maybe because the guy (the owner) knew Rob he felt as if it was acceptable to have us wait a half-hour to be seated in an empty establishment. I asked if he had the place reserved for a party or maybe a series of expected tables, but he just said that most of the tables are unofficially reserved for his regulars. My manager, along with most of the party I was with was upset. When we did get seated it was on a low seating log like furniture. I'm still spry enough to not particularly be bothered by it, but I was the youngest in the group, and most of the people in the clique complain about flying first class for more than a few hours.  All this before we are even served, and on a napkin no less. I understand that the menu consists of small plates, but I (along with the rest my party) felt they are better served on plates than napkins. The worst was yet to come. One of my co-workers gets tired of the owner's non-answers to whether he had actual plates in the kitchen, and decides to get up and ask the busser for plates. The busser gleefully obliges by handing over a dozen or so small plates. Now this is where the situation becomes awkward, the owner breaks into action and snatches the plates from my co-workers hands only to scurry off into the back with them the way my baby son would his fire truck. It turns out he had plates, but just thought it would be easier to not use them. Lastly the wine here is an afterthought, especially with it being a supposed "wine bar". We had some forgettable screw top Malbec that I've seen at Trader Joes for $3.99, I didn't pay so I wasn't too concerned, but $32 is still a much more than the standard three to four time markup.  If you like wine, steer yourself elsewhere, and if you like good food or service....RUN
author: George S.

description:
d organized a little gathering at Yield a couple weeks back, a new wine bar in the latest "up and coming" neighborhood in SF: the Dogpatch.

The former industrial wasteland is slowly being transformed by the familiar incremental steps: gut warehouses and build loft space, open up mid-range restaurants, cafes, eclectic stores, and last but not least: add public transportation.  We went there on a early Saturday evening and while it was dead empty then, by the time we left around 10, it was packed.  Good sign for a new place in a still developing area.

Yield features a nice, balanced assortment of organic wines, including some well-priced ones.  They also have some small plates of course to accompany your wine selection.  We tried several items over the course of the evening: the Sunchoke Parmesan Dip with Toasted Pinenuts was served warm and quite savory and delicious; the Parmesan-Crusted Tartine with Eggplant Confit, Goat Cheese, and Mint was its equal in satisfaction; and the Smoked Fish Trio and the Pcoc Dolce Chocolate Tiles were solid as well. 

Service was friendly and generally attentive.  Nice place to check out if you're in the mood to explore something new.
author: Saminda W.

description:
On my first ever adventure into the dogpatch, I stopped by Yield to have a glass or 2 of wine before heading to dinner down the street. It was a lovely day and a table opened up outside right as I arrived. Perfect. 
I can't remember exactly what I ordered but the selection by the glass was good and our server knew his stuff. Fast forward to a few months later and my second official trip to the dp, I came here again before dinner, with someone who really knows their wine. We had an austrian wine that I'd never heard of and a very drinkable pinot. The staff were very approachable for questions if you had any.
author: Sara P.

description:
When I go out, I usually like to go somewhere nice and cozy. Rarely do I like to get gussied up and bust out my 3.5 heels and big hair. Which is why Yield is perfect for me.

First of all, it's close to home. For a homebody, that's pretty important.

Second of all, there's free street parking. For a San Franciscan and former Los Angelena, that's pretty amazing.

Third of all, the atmosphere is so comfortable. The lighting is dim but not so dim that you can't see if you're sitting on a suspicious stain, the leather couches offer you comfy derriere and back support and you don't have to be dressed to the nines to feel like you fit in.

Fourth of all (I've never actually seen/heard this phrase used...is it actually usable?), the staff (actually, just the one guy we saw) was awesome and had spot-on recommendations. Nic usually works at Pause but happened to be at Yield the first night the Husband and I went and he was awesome. Super friendly, made us feel right at home and the wines he suggested were perfect. I guess it helps that Yield has good wines to begin with but Nic was terrific. Also, the music was great. Fitzgerald + Sinatra is an unbeatable combination.

Fifth of all (again, never heard this but I'm using it), the food was tasty. I heard that it used to be cheaper but the price of everything else is going up so Yield had to yield. We tried the burrata (it came with toast, arugula, some kind of fabulous melon and finishing salt) and the pakora (with two different types of sauce). Good stuff. The table next to us had ordered practically everything else and the cod sliders looked amazing. 

I can't wait to go back. Nic says that Francesca (the brunette) and Maggie (the blond) are just as cool so I'm excited.

P.S. The kitchen closes a little before 10 (Nic came over to us at around 9:50 for last call) so if you're peckish, make sure to get in a bit before then!
author: Christine P.

description:
Ok, lets be honest...who doesn't love wine? If you said yes, then you're probably pretty weird and should just go away...

Now, if you do love wine, then let's talk. Let's talk about Yield Wine Bar and how pretty freaking amazing it is. Not just for wine, but for it's overall goodness.

First off, the wine is spot-on yummy. As a wine enthusiast who can be considered a wine alcoholic, I have tried several different types of wine and didn't have any problems with any of them.

So what's some tasty wine without some equally tasty snacks? Have no worries, because Yield can hook you up with the food like they do the wine. Lots of yummy and seasonal things to whet your palate while you're whetting your palate. Yum yum yum! The staff can suggest to you what you might want depending on your preferred taste, and can tell you what the perfect wine pairing will be.

Which is a perfect segway into our next topic...the staff! I have been multiple times and have always loved my time with Francesca and Nic. Francesca is just all sorts of fun, and is necessary to keep Nic in line. Nic is just a fun and cute fellow to sit and chat with, and not just because he has an awesome name (yay!). Sit at the bar, and you'll love talking with the two of them, being silly and giddy, and perhaps getting yourself into trouble (which, future warning...it'll most likely be because of Francesca...) 

You might be saying "But it's so far away! I would have to take the T-line to get there, and that takes forever!" Well, guess what? Just do it! It's worth it! You'll love the space, the art on the walls, the selection of yummy wine and food, and the folks that'll keep you entertained. Bottom line....yummy yummy yummy ha ha ha more yummy...he end.
author: Nicolas H.

description:
What a find!  My friend and I were looking for a place to have one last glass of wine after the yelp party and I remembered passing by this little spot awhile back.  So many things are right about this place:

Open on a Monday
Super friendly and knowledgeable staff - treated us like old friends
Organic, biodynamic wines
Comfy couches - better than a living room
Delicious Viognier
Clean restroom
Bottle of water right when we sat down

If I owned a wine bar, Yield is how I'd do it.  Definitely going to come back to this spot.
author: Kristin S.

description:
This is my favorite wine bar in San Francisco. The wine list is diverse and dynamic. The food was excellent in quality and quantity, the portions perfect for snacking and complementing the wine. 

The overall atmosphere is comfortable and relaxed. The staff are friendly and very knowledgeable; they were very helpful with recommendations for wines.
author: Katherine E.

description:
Yield is such a welcome addition to my tiny growing neighborhood of Dogpatch. Owner Chris, was the former wine man at Millennium and brings a great knowledge of organic, bio-dynamic (anyone hear the one about the cone of dung?) and sustainable wines to his tiny spot. It is, of course, only a matter of time before the masses will find Yield -- especially once the light rail extension goes online in the next couple of months. But if he keeps roasting the almonds with rosemary, salt and a bit of sugar, I will fight through the throngs to find a glass of Logan Pinot Noir and a seat at Yield.

Update: the recent addition of flatbread pizzas and even more recent Monday openings make this place vital!
author: Andrew S.

description:
Its perfect. Casual, super friendly, wines are all organic, and tasty cheap eats.
Whats not to like?  Plus - they always try to find you a seat.  My go to spot!
author: Lione B.

description:
Super cozy spot that is basically everything you'd want a wine bar to be.  Great wine.  Super friendly and helpful staff.  Awesome decor and cozy set up.  Good for groups.  Nice seating outdoors for those oh so wonderful sunny Potrero/Dogpatch evenings.  Pretty ideal when you're in a wine bar kind of mood (which should be regularly).  

Also, again, super cool staff.  I hadn't been here in probably close to a year yet the guys still recognized me and my wife from the last time we were in and treated us great.  How can you not want to come back to a place like that?
author: Sean H.

description:
This isn't the Dogpatch I wandered around years ago, before the T-Third.  While waiting for friends to show up at a nearby house party, I wandered into Yield for a drink and a snack. The atmosphere was coffeeshop-like, casual, and friendly, with two Oaklandish folks working the wine bar (go figure).

The menu looked good, but I only had time for some olives--which were indeed some of the best marinated ones I've tasted. Great spice blend, and nice use of the crispy garlic bits. The wine list was varied and interesting, the wine was served properly, and the big carafe of water was a nice touch so early in the evening. I do wonder why they didn't have more local product on the menu, though, since there are now a bunch of interesting wineries in the industrial parts of both SF and Oakland.
author: Matt R.

description:
Another excellent wine bar in SF, although it is a little bit out of the way. But that makes for easy parking on a weekend, which I love!

I'm a big fan of tapas and the price & portions of each small plate we ordered was perfect for snacking with wine.  The staff was extremely knowledgeable about the wine list and gave us great recommendations on what to imbibe based on our preferences, and were very friendly and accomodating.This place is comfortable, unpretentious, and welcoming.

For around $25/pp for apps and wine, it's definitely a winner!
author: Janet L.

description:
We happened to be there for happy hour outside on the sidewalk area on a beautiful sunny afternoon.  The Hedgehog Mushroom Rainbow Carrot Ragout was delicious so we ordered the cod sliders.

We also had social conversation with another couple and felt like "neighborhood".  Highly recommend!
author: Catherine C.

description:
Basically - I love Yield and everyone I bring here loves it too.  Anytime I plan a happy hour with someone new, you can count on me saying "have you ever been to Yield?"  Since it is located in the dogpatch not many people seem to get over there.  So I try to tell and bring everyone I know.  

I have been coming here since it opened, and here is why:
1. Service is flawless.
2. Wine list is perfectly chosen.
3. Wine menu changes up frequently enough to keep it interesting, but not so frequent that your fav wine is gone by your next visit.
4. Food menu is yummy, the perfect little bites. 
5. The wine descriptions on the menu exactly describe what you are about to taste and it makes it easy to venture out and try new wines.
6. You can always count on people being there to provide a nice atmosphere, but it isn't overcrowded.
7. Music selection always seems to fit my mood somehow.
8. The art work, you can enoy a glass of wine and debate the meaning.
9. Parking - there actually IS parking near by if not in front. 
10. Got to love that Serpentine is across the street, so Yield is perfect for a pre or post drink after and amazing meal.

Need I say more?
author: Christie A.

description: This place is great for happy hour pricing. $12 carafe? Yes please.  $2 off small plates? I'm in. It's nice and cozy, and not too crowded. Background music  and lighting were good too. All that being said, I'm not a wine buff, so I can't really speak to the "selection" but in general if you can get a carafe for $12, why not just enjoy it? Maybe there's such a thing as too snobby when it comes to drinks.
author: Earl M.

description:
I was looking for a nice, simple venue to host a party for a group of friends to mingle without blaring music or a stuffy crowd. Not to mention, a different wine bar tried to charge a $1K min for just my 20 friends, but Yield did not. In fact, Chris helped me with my reservation and he was very accommodating, understanding that people come at different times and gave the option for the area with standing room.

The venue has a good vibe that my friends enjoyed. The service was great, and you can't go wrong with the $5 food menu and a decent wine selection. The cod cakes were killer, by the way!

For those commuting, street parking was easy to find and it's along a couple Muni Metro lines.
author: Maybelle M.

description:
wine - 5/5
food - 3/5 
service - 1/5

very good selection of wine, with several organic and biodynamic selections. fun little tapas-style plates. i was impressed by the salad with pistachios and vanilla vinaigrette, for one.

our servers didn't pay much attention at all, however. we were consistently trying to get his or her attention for more water, more water again, an extra wine glass for a newcomer, or to order food. we never received little plates to eat our tapas on (7 of us were sharing - isn't that standard?) and ended up sort of eating them directly from the serving plates.

wines were excellent though. i'd like to come back with a friend and sit at the bar.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
What a great place for a low-key happy hour in the Dogpatch!  

Casual-chic, intimate, and relaxed.  I'm such an amateur wine drinker but this place is not intimidating at all.  My wine loving friends agreed that the wine selection was very nice.

The plus:  Parking is a breeze.  The atmosphere, is unintimidating, and the food is great!  

The minus:  They made two mistakes on our bill at the end of the night (that happened the first time I went too).  Also, the server gave us a hard time about using their used and dirty paper menus to write a note.
author: Angella S.

description:
Yield ia great for a couple of very specific reasons. 
1. They arent trying to hard to be a "wine spot"
2. They have good wine and some snacks to go with it.

You can also drink outdoors if the weather is right.
author: Joseph M.

description:
[Reviewed by Kel]

For wine bars, this is about as good as it gets. I adore this place! It's comfortable, unpretentious, and welcoming. The staff is sincere and extremely knowledgeable about the wine list. Plus, all of the bites on the menu are only $5. And I do say 'bites' because the portions are quite small. But, for the inexpensive price, the quality is wonderful. I've paid much more for mediocre food at other wine bars. I think this would be the perfect spot to take some visitors to, who want to get a feel for what the real SF is all about.

Came here with a group of girlfriends and I believe we each spent about $25-ish for multiple tapas plates (enough to make me full) plus wine. Yup, it was a good night.
author: Kel S.

description: I love Yield! The friendly faces here recommend and accommodate guests very well in the process of fine wine selection. They have a few tables with stools and a couple of comfy couches. The warmth of this cozy vino venue makes it a great place to meet with friends and share some laughs, relax, draw pictures, or tell your life story. I love this local spot and for those traveling by car, parking in this neck of the city is glorious.
author: Jaime L.

description:
Definitely one of my favorite wine bars in SF. It's a great neighborhood wine bar. My go-to date spot or casual Friday happy hour. 

The wine list is always interesting and I often get to taste wines I've been wanting to try from smaller, lesser-known wineries - or discover something new.

I love the industrial feel and most of all, the friendly, relaxed staff. (in this case "relaxed" is not code word for slow or anything negative; more like helpful and they give you time to make decisions and are willing to help).

The only con has nothing to do with Yield, but the location on 3rd means it's hard to catch a cab home.
author: Erica S.

description:
I swear to Mariah, it took one billion trillion balloons tied to my old two-story house just to get to this remote boonies area of San Francisco known mysteriously as the "Dog Patch." 

After many close-calls with tall buildings, wayward birds and violent storms, I finally arrived at my destination: Yield Wine Bar.

Was Yield Wine Bar worth this dangerous and foreverlong journey? It's hard to say.

The limited food menu was pretty good, albeit a bit pricey. 

The Chevre-Stuffed Medjool Dates were marvelous, the oyster plater standard fare (although the pop-rocks-seasoned oyster with a birthday candle was a great touch and tooootally weird and awesome), the Warm Spinach Dip had a slight chalky undertone (like goat cheese-esque) (but not bad), and the stuffed endives were tasty like Coko's pastries (if you get this, marry me please). 

But you come here for the wine, right?

Unfortunately, Yield was out of the one Riesling on the menu the night I went... which, sorry to say, is like going to a bar and ordering a gin & tonic but they're out of gin....... :| We ended up ordering a suggested alternative white along with another red, neither of which I personally was a fan of.

The bartender/host with the bleached blonde hair was perfectly adorable and quirky. The chef popped out for a minute, but like a fetus who decided to be unborned, popped back into the kitchen just as soon; it was bizarre and cute.

So in conclusion, if you're anything like me, a classy wine bar like this place is not really your cup of tea, but if you don't really ever trip about spending that cash and don't mind a fantastic voyage just to get to this remote jungle/outer limits, then as far as wine bars go, Yield is definitely not bad.

11/9... Never Forget
author: Joshua L.

description:
Clearly I haven't been getting out as much as I thought I have been, or perhaps I've been getting out but in all the wrong areas! 

Came to meet a friend here a few weeks ago, all I have to say is this was the cutest, coziest wine bar I have been in a very long time. If I lived closer, I would cozy up with a glass of wine there on a regular basis. 

This time around I did not get to explore their food menu, but that's an option. Will definitely come visit again. 

The service was awesome too, the servers just had a fun playful attitude :)
author: yana Z.

description: Really really good wine and great service. Very cute little wine bar.
author: Koshika S.

description: This is a pretty good wine bar. They have not as many by the glass selections as I'd hoped for but honestly, who are you fooling? You'll end up wanting a full bottle anyway. They could flush out their menu a bit too, only 2 cheeses? Nice staff & funky little fire thingy in the side room.
author: Colleen B.

description: This has become my go-to wine bar in SF. I love the warmth and charismatic charm of the Owner and the rest of the Yield employees. Tuesday night trivia is the best night of the week. Nic's happy and fun personality is contagious. It's impossible not to laugh and smile over a glass of wine (or three) when he is around. The wine is amazing. The food is great--you won't be disappointed by the cheese plate, which I sometimes find myself ordering twice in one night. Meeting with friends and enjoying a bottle of wine here has quickly become of my favorite SF pastimes. So thankful to have this place in the neighborhood.
author: Amanda H.

description: Rainy day, sunny disposition. Our server could not have been friendlier or more welcoming. The happy hour $12 half carafe is a good deal and the fried brussels sprouts and cheddar dip a full meal for a rainy nite. Not afraid of chili, yay. So comfortable, i feel like a mini vakay when i visit. Now serving pescaderarian brunch sat/sun 10-2, lookin forward to it.
author: Kelly K.

description:
The place itself gives off a very cool and inviting feeling.  I loved the couch area and the little fireplace in the other room, where my friend and I sat.
I would love to try a few more of their bites, but we just wanted to see the place and spend my friend's gift certificate.


Riezling: Good wine, wasn't crazy sweet OR crazy expensive
marinated olives: This was GOOD.  They were warm and the spices on them were great.  I loved the chips of garlic in it too, yumm.

Overall: I would love to come back and try their other stuff.  Also, the servers were really nice and very soft... went very well with the atmosphere of the place.
author: Isabella O.

description:
Most progressive wine bar in San Francisco, nestled in the Dogpatch, serves only organic, biodynamic, and sustainable wines. Decor is warm dark wood tones and comfortable distressed couches, with stools along the bar and at a handful of tables.

I waltzed in on a slow Tuesday night after getting off Caltrain from work to find two of the owners of this local, green business, relaxed in the comfortable space.
