I was pleased to learn of their successful venture, enjoy wine with them, and walk away with a copy of their self-published "Green Wine" book!
author: Jake G.

description:
As soon as I entered the bar, the waiter greeted me nicely and showed me to a table. I was waiting for my friend so felt a little awkward at first but he made me feel right at home.  You know a hot girl sitting in a bar by herself relays a certain message (cheeseball...).
Anyhow, I tried the Frappato Centoze (bright and light red, not tannin), Syrah/Grenache/Mourvedre which was definitely bold and had the fig notes which I really liked. You can order a 1/2 a glass too so I had 1/2 a glass of Cabernet Sauvignon, Tsantali Organics.  I liked it alot as well-smooth cab and dry.  She had the Sangiovese which was ok for me as Sangiovese's do have a little medicinal flavor that I'm not that fond of.  
Foodwise, we tried the stuffed figs (delish: sweet, nutty and moist). The cod sliders are pan fried and moist; they were accompanied with french fries which reminded me of McDonald's fries (Like). We had the hard cheese plate garnished with sliced strawberries, grapes and acme bread.
All in all-really good service with a pleasant, casual atmosphere. Unmetered street parking is a big Plus. I'd give it a 5 though have only been there once.
author: Quan T.

description:
Great place to hang around with friends - 
We went there early on Monday, so the place was not busy when we got there. I like it that way and we were able to have a good conversation.
Ordered several glasses of wine and they were all good or decent.  We also had the spinach dip, and it was quite good. 
Parking was not too hard, and the area is an industrial area, not sure how the area got the name of Dogpatch.. ??
Definitely a great place. Thumbs up!
author: Lena N.

description:
This place is not in my hood and I stopped by to kill some time and avoid traffic and was pleasantly surprised. 

Good selection of wines and the price points are reasonable. Staff is friendly and the space is mellow.

Very much a neighborhood gem.
author: G R.

description:
Yield to the Caltrain and get your butt to Yield.

This wine bar is great!  They have a really good selection of wines at all price points - from $5 to $12/glass.  The waiters are great about helping you pick a good wine and selecting a small plate that you'll like.

We came here on a Friday night and found a parking spot really close by!  Imagine that.  We had a few glasses of wine and small plates.  It wasn't too crowded, but was a really lively bunch.  We weren't too hungry, so just shared small plates - if you're starving, I'd say eat somewhere else closeby and then have a drink here.  Otherwise, you'll either starve or spend a million dollars.

Overall, Yield is awesome... and I'll definitely be back.  There are a lot of cool places to check out in the dogpatch... and a lot of cool people to meet once you get there.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Like the neighborhood-ish vibe;  A couple even brought their baby in a stroller so that's kinda nice to know that couples with babies can still find a place to chill and sip wine.  1/2 of the place is dimmer with barstool seating and 1/2 of it is brighter with couches type seating, to cater to different type of audience.

Their wine feels a bit pricey, but the Malbec/Cab Franc wine I had was very good, I must say.   For food, they offered a selection of 4 small plates, 4 cheese/bread plates, and 4 small chocolates ranging from $4 to $6 a plate. 

After we had drinks, we went over to Serpentine for a few small plates since the food here is really just small, small bites.

This place is definitely on the pricier size since the 2 of us had 2 glasses of wine, 1 savory plate and 1 cheese plate and that was $40 while we had 2 glasses of wine and 3 small plates, dessert and coffee at Serpentine for $55.
author: Irene C.

description:
Great wines, tremendously delicious hors d'oevres, what's not to like?  In fact, parking in the early evening is really easy so that right there takes care of a big problem, and there is a MUNI stop right there, so that facilitates a lot.

Goat chesse stuffed figs is the premiere tasty appetizer, but there is so much more.  It's been awhile, but my vegan friend whom joined in had plenty to choose from, so lots of good choices.

I shall definitely return.
author: Miss C.

description:
Yield is a great, unpretentious place to enjoy a glass of wine with some good company.  As others will tell you, the place is about the ambiance and organic & biodynamic wine.  Found the appetizers reasonable and interesting in content.  Walking around, seems like the place can hold about 50 people.  I'll definitely check out their carafe next time during happy hour!

Food: 4/5
Ambiance: 4.5/5
Service: 4/5
Value: 3/5
author: King L.

description:
Yield is a great, neighborhood wine bar. The wines are interesting and dedicated to organic and/or sustainable farming practices. Better for you and the environment. When it comes to wine, that's a win-win! 

I take wine seriously and love the fact that Chris' tight wine list is always unique, varied, and value-oriented. You can't go wrong with the carafe either. 

The food is also good. There's the standard but enjoyable cheese plate and snacks but also some delicious plates. It seems to change regularly.

Actually, one of my favorites things about Yield is the staff and service. I've been here many times and every time, they are friendly, on the ball, and knowledgeable.
author: Danielle L.

description: Very cute and cozy place. Great feel. Good prices. Awesome wines. Never been let down. My dad makes us take him here every time he visits SF now. Even when we say we're going to "try something new", we still end up here at some point in the evening.
author: Joey M.

description:
What a delightful spot near the trolley line to rest your seat and drink some wine,
With 5 dollar treats and wines galore you'll be begging for some more,
Sit outside and enjoy the sun and the waiters make it much more fun,
Silders and cheese dip with a rose,
When your done you'll stumble on your way,
Cheers to Yield, My wallet wont be sealed!
author: M K.

description:
I went to a private party here the other day so I didn't quite get the true Yield experience.

I'm not a San Francisco native, but I did live here for grade school and high school, so that practically makes me a lifer. When I was a kid-- and we had to suffer through MUNI, rather than suffering through trying to park our sports cars on the crowded SF streets-- I had never even heard of the Dogpatch. Hell, areas like South Beach and Mission Bay were little more than shipping yards and warehouse districts where the old Embarcadero free way trailed off into the sunset. 

Now, Dogpatch is cool, I think. To me, it looks like an area of, say, Allentown, PA or a suburb of Detroit, except it has adorable wine bars like Yield near some art galleries and cool brunch spots to punctuate the industrial blight and homeless men harassing me as I walk.

So, yeah. I know little about Yield, but it seems cool. I'd never drive all the way out there just for drinks. But they did let me bring my dog in the bar, which is cool-- and so French!-- and the mango salsa stuffed into those endive slices punctuated by Pinot Grigio was awesome.

Dogpatch. I'll say.
author: Ross S.

description: Sweet, neighborhood wine bar. Great pours, friendly staff, good wine list. This is the place to go when you want a light bite and a glass (or two) of wine. Pescetarian friendly tapas and a small selection of good beer.
author: Sirima S.

description: A great late night find while keeping company for a friend catching the CalTrain. The service was the best ever and the couch oh-so-comfy, oh and the wine was good too :) I can't wait to get somebody to meet me here after work for happy hour (hint, hint, hint!!!)
author: Tatyana K.

description: EXCELLENT experience here for my husband's birthday celebration. From the first time I called to inquire about having a special event, to the moment my group arrived, the customer service was top notch.  Nic took care of us as if we were family -- that is a rare and remarkable experience.  The wine was great, the food was more substantial than typical bar snacks, and the space was lovely. Despite being a small place, our group fit comfortably in the side room, which basically felt like our own private room. Water jugs and glasses were set up for us without anyone having to ask. I will DEFINITELY be going back, and even going out of my way, to visit again and again.
author: Molly P.

description:
Overall: 5
Every time I leave this place I say to myself how I should come here more often. I wish more wine bars were like this.

Service: 5
Big pours and friendly service.

Ambiance: 5
Tons of chicks! I always come with my girlfriend but if I were a single guy on the prowl this would be a great spot to catch some eye candy. Also, a great place to have a nice quiet conversation on a date.

Value: 4
Great wines and filling appetizers. Very affordable in comparison to other wine bars.

Decor: 5
I feel like I'm in someone's house. Not pretentious.
author: Roger H.

description: most places i go to that dub themselves "wine bars" serve the worst wine.  But Yield lives up to its name.  Plus the food and service are excellent.  Also, being in the Dog Patch, there is a totally chill vibe.  The place is never overcrowded, and you don't get the "i'm too cool for everyone" crowd you find at other wine bars.  love it.
author: Ash T.

description:
Yield is that rare kind of wine bar: All at once unassuming, accessible, uncrowded & reasonably priced. The kind of wine bar a non-snob can appreciate. They have handy 'nose/note' descriptions next to each selection. For example, the first glass I ordered used descriptors like "earth" & "barnyard" (or something like that). I ordered it mostly out of curiosity, & it was delicious. Your average snooty SF wine bar would never invoke horse poop & hay when describing a wine. One of the many reasons I liked Yield. Oh, & the service was friendly & attentive.

I'm not going to speak to the theory that the area around Third Street (AKA the Dogpatch) is entering a slow & beautiful cultural explosion. Let's let time & gravity show us how that goes.
author: Pete J.

description:
Great vibe -- very warm and inviting space.  LOVE the alcohol-fueled stove warming up the place, as well as the very affable host.  Owner and host were both very accomodating, and made great suggestions as to which wines we might like.

We had a couple of small-plate starters and wines to match... wish we'd had more time as some of their more substantial treats looked to good to pass up -- but we were dining at Serpentine (just across the street) and didn't want to fill up prior.

Highly recommend this place, and will definitely come back with wife in tow for a more romantic visit.
author: Don N.

description:
I went to Yield last night, for the first time, after stumbling across it on Yelp. I rather hurriedly chose it while on the phone with my colleague making plans to meet at a mutually convenient location. I live in SF, she lives in Pacifica... it took us both about 15 minutes to get here. It's quite conveniently located just off the freeway.

I am partial to the funky Dogpatch neighborhood, and so was excited by the location. However, this little place won me over with its warm atmosphere, friendly service, and insanely delicious food. The wine, this is a wine bar after all, was great, but I will admit I only tried the happy hour special (which changes each day). The carafe served up two very large glasses of wine, for $10. The particular variety was one that I like, so it did have an advantage. We were so happy with it, we ordered nothing else to drink!

I also give kudos for the fact that their wines are all certified organic, most bio-dynamic in some way. I was worried that this would mean the wine wasn't very good, but I loved it, as I mentioned.

The restaurant is divided into two areas, the cozy couch/ottoman area which feels very homey... like someone has a bar in their loft living room. And on the right side they have tall table and bar stools; sparse, but cozy nonetheless, with a chalkboard menu and a little denatured alcohol flame running in the room.

I would be remiss if I failed to mention the food, which was an afterthought for us (we had not come to eat, really). We chose the watermelon and heirloom tomato salad (the taste summer right there), the fried okra (which might have been the best I've ever had), and a creamy spinach dip (with this parmesan crisp on the top that was to die for)... all I can say is don't leave with out trying *something* from their short, seasonal menu. The prices were quite reasonable, and well worth the delight of eating them.

I will be going there again very soon; great place to take a client, a date, or a group of friends.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Ventured into Dogpatch for the first time last night with Rachel F. to check out Yield...

This is a great little neighborhood wine bar.  The atmosphere is relaxed and professional...but not so much so that it's pretentious.  They play AWESOME music here and serve amazing wines that are all organic (for those of you whom that makes a difference for!)

Last night I had one of the best wine's I've ever had...which says a lot as I've tried a lot of wines.  It was the Sky Saddle Zinfandel ($14/glass).  What was interesting about this wine was that it didn't taste like a Zinfandel to me.  It was smooth and buttery, and delicious!  The bartenders were very attentive and friendly (especially since we kept hounding them to tell us the name of the bands that were on the iPod!) and overall, I really liked this joint.  I think if I lived closer I'd be here more often....but even so, I think Rachel F and I are planning on coming here more often!

And I can't wait to explore Dogpatch a little more....lots of interesting bars, bistros and cafes! :-)
author: Melanie N.

description:
Don't ask anyone at Yield if they have any organic suggestions. The whole menu is organic! 
Do ask them for suggestions. They know their stuff. 

Don't stick your hand in the funny little firebox. It is real fire and will burn you.

Do lounge comfortably in the low black leather chairs. They are meant for taking a load off.

Don't use the bathroom for your own personal lounge. There's only one restroom available in the whole place.

Do order a few plates of food and share with friends. They're designed to share.
author: Kat E.

description: Excelente ambience, great wines and wonderful small plates. We had a few glasses of a Croatian red (Plavic Mali) which was super smooth and hard to find at most wine places. As far as food, we ordered the artichoke, kale and parmesan dip along with a flatbread (The Hub). Both were delicious, but the flatbread and the service made this a five star experience for us.
author: Rick C.

description:
This cozy little place is one of my new favorites.  

The atmosphere could be warmer, but the service is great: totally unpretentious and helpful. 

Excellent food, especially  the stuffed dates (i don't even like dates!)  

I love trying new wines, and I think they have a nice variety.
author: Mollie T.

description:
The wine selection is pretty good!  I found the food menu on the chalkboard really cute and charming.  After ordering a couple of the items (all 3 cheese selections) and the calamari - I understood why they were only $5 each.... the portions are incredibly small... I felt like an ogre not having enough food.  The pieces were actually cut in SMALL pieces.  It also didn't have much flavor... the aioli that came with it was completely bland.  But I get it, it's a wine bar, not a restaurant.  The food is mediocre, but the wine is yums. 

Click here to read more about the customer service.
http://tlbooey.wordpress.com/2010/04/01/yield-not-when-it-comes-to-wine-keep-it-coming/

All in all, I dig the spot - I'd definitely go back if I was ever in that area.....
author: ThaoLinh B.

description: I never thought I'd call a place with a modern/industrial decor "cozy," but somehow this place is just that.  It could have been the nifty port-a-fire shelf thingy on the wall next to us, or the friendly wine doods, or the happy mix of music.  It could have been that I knew the yummy wine I was drinking was grown in an earth-friendly kinda way or the fact that there were unexpected yet quite appropriate blood oranges on my bruschetta.  It could have been the company of an old friend sharing a tender story.  Or it could have been all of the above hiding out from a rainy day, quietly yielding to mellow.
author: Andi T.

description:
UPDATE (10/15):

All I can say is - Wow!  On a quiet, cold night I arrived back at Yield after a long hiatus and was completely won over by the excelleent knowledge and friendly service here.  Our server steered me in the perfect direction, offered a tasting pour of a wine that was not on the list as a taste option and and was generally attentive without being overbearing.  She knew the list extremely well and could speak about all of it with authority - we were quite safe in her hands.

We also ordered a cheese plate, which was properly proportioned for the price (alliteration - couldn't resist).  

My one major issue with Yield is the lighting.  It's way too dark in there.  I kept wanting to find the lights and turn them up about five degrees - the current lighting setup provides a dim, yellowish gloom that is difficult to see in and rather unappetizing as well.  Besides, at my age I prefer to avoid squinting - no wrinkles before their time, dammit!

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
Must come here again.

Must come here again.

I kept thinking, as I strained to overhear the friends sitting thisclosetome, that I really must come here again...when they are not having a huge private party.  

Yield will most likely never be on my normal rotation, mostly because it is far off my path, but the interesting looking space and obviously knowledgeable people behind the bar will bring me back again.  Even with a huge, loud and demanding group in the place we still got a bit of personalized attention.  And the wine list - with its environmental edge - provides several wines I haven't seen elsewhere that (key concept!) also look interesting.  

Must, must , must come here again.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
I almost don't want to write this review.  Yield is a rare gem and I don't want everyone and their brother stealing all the seats!  100 words or less:  Intimate, cozy, approachable wine list by the glass, even more approachable staff, Farmhouse-Modern decor (refurbished wood beams, counter, & tables, warm earth-tones, industrial location ... understated style.  

The wine list is awesome.  Why?  Because each listing is accompanied by a great description.  Sometimes I wonder how anyone's palate could be that discerning (think 0.05 extra fine mechanical pencil graphite, sun-dried starfruit, , semi-dry peat moss... those are my own descriptions, but seriously some of the taglines are just as ..."obtuse"?  But I appreciate them A LOT.  My trouble in choosing, if I have trouble, lies in there usually being more than one that i want to wrap my lips around.  On that note, they are really generous with tastes.  And the pours are definitely more than the typical 5 oz pours at stingier establishments.  

Yield is worth the drive to Dogpatch.  You won't have any trouble finding parking and you might fall in love just like I did.  I am smitten.

One random note: the bathroom is GIGANTIC!  And as cold as a meat locker!  Go figure.
author: Meadow L.

description:
Dogpatch? Jeez SF, I finally was able to recognize that I was in Potrero Hill and now you gotta go and throw a Dogpatch in there. Sheesh, too confusing.

What wasn't confusing was how I felt about my time at Yield. I liked it and I definitely enjoyed my time here thanks to the company of the sassy and hysterical Jay H. I swear we must have pissed the world off here with our loud laughs and my retelling of the worst book I've read in years called the Naughty Neighbor. Gotta love a bad plane book :) Eeesh.

The wine was nice, although not ass kickasstastic and manly as I generally like it. I ordered the Shiraz and it had enough of a kick to make it just so so for me, but coming from a bad ass Tempranillo at District before, I think my palate was a little bummed.

I really liked the look of the place and the glass blocks above the wine bar make for a pretty comfortable visual and the couches were very comfy. Overall, I'm not sure if this is a place I would pull a Whitney Houston and "Run to youuuuuuu oooooooohhhhhh" over, but I would pop in if I was in the neighborhood as few things can pull me away from a night involving wine! :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
Selection: 4
Value: 3+
Service: 4
Decor: 3+
Atmosphere: ?

I have high hopes for Yield.  I stopped in last night and enjoyed three glass of good to very good wine for a total of $23.  A good value, especially when compared to recent disappointments at Nectar and Cav.

Every wine Yield carries is produced using biodynamic, organic, or sustainable methods.  A big plus in my book.  About half of the 50 or so wines Yield offers are available by the glass.  With the help of Chris, the co-owner and principal server, I selected wines near the low end of Yield's per glass price range of $6 to $14.

Yield is now serving some yummy-looking small plates including, of course, cheese.  I didn't sample them, so will report back when I do.

The space is comfortable and their music was great -- I plan on returning shortly with a big posse of friends to rock the joint.  The second room, off from the bar, didn't look particularly inviting.  Yield would benefit by putting a few more touches on its decor and furnishings.

The key to Yield's success is going to be making a name for itself in the Dog Patch and gaining a strong following from locals like me.  Is the hood ready for a wine bar?  I don't know, but I sure as help hope so.
author: Nate B.

description:
Does red wine give you a headache, even after only one glass?  Or perhaps white wine gives you a stuffy nose?  Yeah, me too.  But I've discovered the secret to avoiding those side effects.  Drink Old World (e.g., European) wine and/or wines that don't contain added preservatives or pesticides.  You can find both at Yield Wine Bar.

While Yield offers an assortment of Old and New World wines, all wines are organic, biodynamic, and/or sustainable, which means they won't have that extra junk in there that makes you hurt.   The best part is you won't sacrifice taste.  The wines I've tried there have all been excellent, and they're affordable to boot.

Great wine aside, I have many other positive things to say about this place.  It's a bit of industrial mixed with a lot of class, and the ambient lighting will make you (and your sweetie) look good.  The music is diverse and well-picked, so each song adds even more flavor to the atmosphere.   And all of the food items I've tried have been tasty.

So put your pain-relievers away and head down to Yield to rediscover why wine has been making people feel good for thousands of years.  Just don't drink too many bottles at once or you might have to pull out the aspirin after all.
author: MA f.

description:
Mark my words, the Dogpatch is one of the next big neighborhoods in the city.  With Just for You and now Yield Wine Bar, you can say you were there when...

Sunday afternoon at Yield.  It's like being in your living room with your friends, but more comfy, with better music and lighting and with someone bringing you freaking great wine.  

I love the wine selection -- many great options from Anderson Valley and elsewhere.  It is diverse without being overwhelming.  AND, they are all organic, biodynamic or sustainable.  I won't drink anything else anymore!!  And, Chris, one of the owners, is a gem.  Ask him to flex his avocado tattoo for you.

Update:  they've added some additional food options that are worth trying.  Also, get the Gewirtz (Lazy Creek), the Zin (Green & Red), and one of the dessert wines that I can't remember now, but it's sooooo good (white, but not too sweet).
author: Jenn S.

description:
I love the Dogpatch, first off. I love the easy parking, and the industrial feel of it all. 

And I love this little diamond in the rough.

First-off, I'm a wine-o. I love all things red and this place satisfies that itch. The menu seemed a bit overwhelming at first, but the waitress helped me out with a few suggestions of some good pinots. And I got to have tasters of a few instead of just one glass, which is always fun for this Napa Valley gal. 

With its mellow happy vibe and good lighting it makes for a great first date place.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Why you should check out Yield:

1. You have a car OR you live in Potrero or Dogpatch OR you're on your way to/from Mighty, Slow Club, Universal Cafe or Hard Knox Cafe.

2. You like good wine.  

3. You know what biodynamic means.

4. You appreciate beautiful reclaimed wood tables, sweet leather chairs, sturdy suede ottomons, good iPod music, and cool local art.

5. You like good cheese.

6. You like supporting cool people who have a good philosophy and laid-back knowledge of what they're talking about.

7. You like Millennium's wine list (Chris, the owner, used to be the wine guy there.)
author: Melanie C.

description:
If you're tired of the Amalie's, Cav's and Hotel Biron try moving out into the dogpatch for perhaps the best wine bar in SF. 

Small, intimate with soft lighting, they carry a small but very good wine list at reasonable prices.  The wine list changes monthly here but they seem to always carry one of my favorite whites (I dont even care much for white) Albarino every time.  

Last time it smelled like chlorine in here but outside of that ---this place is as solid as they come.
author: Morgan H.

description:
The atmosphere of Yield fits in with their purpose - to offer organic and bio dynamic wines and support family-run wineries.  They are a casual neighborhood place, sitting nicely in the Dogpatch, evoking curious passers-by without screaming attention to themselves.  The staff has an an informed, but not at all in-your-face approach.  The decor is minimal and urban/rustic, and service is helpful and relaxed.  You could almost call it a quiet passion.

With a crop of new wine bars popping up in the city, we now have a large offering of the more elegant, dressed-up versions to choose from.  Yield is different, in a very refreshing way. The materials used in the interior are eco-friendly, and you can find their sources on the website.    Its style is understated hip, dark and atmospheric with great music, a place where you make your own experience with the people that you come with and what you bring in.  

I'm telling you all of this because it would be easy to overlook the subtleties of this place - especially with the senses overload that we are all used to.

Green Bunny and I had a nice time there on a recent weekday evening.   We sipped the recommended Syrah (excellent), nibbled on a cheese plate (small, but satisfying), and caught up on our lives (fascinating, of course).

It's a quick trip on the T from downtown, or just off of the 280 if you are driving.
author: Liz S.

description: I love this wine bar. Their Tuesday night trivia is so much fun. The wine selection is always good. Their flatbread pizzas are teeny tiny but always delicious. I haven't had a bad one yet. The Brussels sprouts are my favorite.
author: Christine N.

description: Great staff, great wine and great food!  Trivia is super fun and the best night to go!  Gets crowded so show up early.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Agree that Yield seems out of place in the Dogpatch.  Next door is a salon where we saw two guys almost passed out on the counter.

Entering Yield makes you forget that this is still a neighborhood in transition, except when the 15 bus stops every 10 minutes to let people out.  The decor and the vibe are thoughtful and comfortable.

Talking to the owners was the best part.  They made wine suggestions and discussed the business with ease.  Their passion is what makes the place successful.

Interestingly enough, the lack of a full menu means that people will stop by and not stay too long, which is perfect considering that it's a cozy place.

Was there with a big group.  Will try to venture back on my own or with a friend.  Maybe even walk there?
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I just wanted to leave more love...
These guys are SO GREAT.
Every time I go in there I swear, I have the best glass of wine I've ever had. I always bring my out of town visitors in because they are so close to my crib, and they NEVER disappoint.
They have salted chocolates on their menu right now, OUT OF THIS WORLD GOOD!
 And they are the sweetest people. 

Yes'um.
author: Kellie P.

description:
After reading the Yelp reviews, I stopped by Yield with a friend (JB) on a Monday night. Note: the wine bar is now open on Monday nights. Parking was not an issue at 9:15p on Monday. 

There were a few other folks. JB and I settled ourselves into the leather section sofa underneath the front window. Immediately, water is brought to our table and wine lists placed in front of us. We were in a serious talking mood so instead of asking for flights or tastings, we both reached into our respective minds and asked for wines from specific regions. 

Chris, the owner, had a Petite Syrah from Dry Creek Valley (my new favorite wine region in Sonoma). He knows his wines well. My friend JB managed a 60 seat fine dining establishment in her previous life and was talking Italian wines with Chris. 

The bathroom was spotless. I wondered aloud if it would be just as clean on a Friday night and Chris said, "Yes, I make sure of it."

Chris was friendly but knew when to walk away and leave us to our discussion. Music was alternately soft and loud, which was a bit strange. However, he even played Patsy Cline...gotta love that. Despite us being the only folks in the bar from 10p till 11p, Chris showed no signs of kicking us out. Very gracious. 

I would like to return here on another night and do some tastings (if allowed) and also inquire if there are flights. Plus, I want to try some of the vegan food as described in other reviews. I wonder if the kitchen was closed on a Monday night? Our menus were of wines, no food and I forgot to ask.

My glass of wine, by the way, was $15...generous pour, robust and fruity but not too sweet. Normally, I do not like Petite Syrah, but I will try anything from Dry Creek Valley. I'm hoping that Chris will offer Zinfandel from Dry Creek by the glass (right now it's by the bottle) in the near future. JB hopes Chris will carry Marchesi di Barolo Ruvei Barbera d' Alba. 

Again, this was the PERFECT place to go for a mellow Monday night talk.

I look forward to my next visit.
author: Grace C.

description:
The gang from work went here after work one evening and it was great! This is from my friend/co-worker Andrei, who has yet to create an account, so I'm "yelp*ing" him...

"Chris Tavelli has started this wonderful wine bar with a commitment to sustainable, organic and biodynamic wines.  I had three different wines, which any of you who know me will attest is unusual.  Chris is still working on getting his warm plates going but has some wonderful cheeses, olives, almonds and chocolate to accompany the wine.  

The atmosphere is very pleasant --- Chris and his father made the tables from reclaimed old redwood beams.  These set amongst comfy club-like chairs and stools.  The paintings are mixed media --- very interesting with rural landscapes worked into wood trimmed in copper.  Very warm and earthy.  Creative lighting and a straightforward clean space make it an easy place to be in and to relax.  

Chris is clearly passionate about what he is doing and comes from many years in the local restaurant industry.  He feels like the type of person running the type of business that progressive people will want to support.  We need more businesses like Yield --- especially here in our evolving DogPatch area of the city.  Parking is not a problem.  Prices are very fair --- especially for organics.  This is the type of place that it feels good to support, so I wanted to pass on the feeling."
author: Dru D.

description:
Went to Yield for a small get together with coworkers at my new job.

It definitely has the right feel to the place. I like the atmosphere and the location is actually pretty good. Parking isn't bad around there and the 48, T and 22 all stop within a block of the place.

Now I'm not a big wine guy, I couldn't tell you what's a good wine from a bad one. However I do know what a good wine when I taste one.

I believe we tried 3 or 4 different wines. I'll say that they weren't bad but they weren't anything that stood out to me. I think that the vineyards they source their wines from need to mature a little and hone their skills at making a smoother more mellow wine. 

The ones we did drink seems quite dry and a bit too sour at least for my taste. I honestly can't remember which ones we drank. That may or may not be a good thing. 

I will have to say that the appetizers were really good! The spinach dip was excellent!. Just need larger portions, it was too small, especially when you like it a lot!
author: Leo V.

description: Me and a few friends stumbled upon this little gem while we were exploring the dog patch. Very nice laid back interior, and the couches and seats were very comfortable. A little on the pricey side, but the wine was delicious. I had a riesling white wine and it was great paired with some cheese or french fries (yes french fries lol). Plus, there was only one guy working the entire place and he was actually on top of it. Service was very quick and prompt, and he had a great sense of humor. Its definitely a great place to unwind after a long day. I'd definitely go back in the near future. I only wish this place was in central downtown, its a little off the beaten path.
author: Evin C.

description:
I love Yield Wine Bar.

It is a great neighborhood bar to meet friends or to unwind after work.  Their reds are excellent and their cheese plate (brie + blue) is amazing.  The people are friendly and good-looking.  

The only thing I'd change would be the stools that are not the most comfortable.

Highly recommended!
author: Jun B.

description:
Green means go, Red means stop, Wine means Yield

When a place becomes a verb it has truly arrived. Over the past few months since Yield opened not only have we frequented the Establishment 1-2 times a week, but it has also become a verb among my friends. We don't go to the wine bar...we go Yielding.  

We enjoy the fresh range of bio-dynamic and organic wines, as diverse as the patrons that show up most nights. The company is always good, the owners Chris and Celine are always friendly and recommend the latest and greatest for your drinking pleasure.

It's a great place to hit after work for happy hour and some starters, stop through before dinner out or a place to wind up (before midnight) to finish out the evening with a mellow glass of wine. 

I've celebrated promotions, birthdays and countless other life events there and I'm sure there will be many more.

Be sure to truly the Lazy Creek if you're lucky enough to find it still on the menu.
author: Derek D.

description:
-   Environmentally Friendly.

-   Only "green" wine bar in San Francisco.

-   Wines are made from grapes that are organically and bio-dynamically farmed.

-   Simple, yet classy identity (I love the logo for some reason) and atmosphere.

I'M SOLD.  

Not so fast.  Came here with two of my girl friends last night after a wonderful dinner at Circolo.  My first impression about Yield... I was disappointed. 

The place was dark and I liked the feel of it, nice decor (art work and fire structure was cool), but there was a funny smell that lingered inside which bothered me.  We sat at a table towards the back facing the window.  The service was a bit awkward, we didn't need two people checking up on us... one would have been fine.  

Only two (2) kinds of dessert wines (tawny port and late harvest)... WTF.  Port for Celeste, Late harvest for Miss Kitty and the sparkling Chardonnay for Si-Eun.  Kitty and I liked our wines, it was good, the port was served chilled.  Si-Eun wasn't too happy with hers considering it was recommended by one of the wait staff.  She sent it back and ended up getting a glass of sparkling Shiraz which was so much better.  With our wines, we each had a chocolate tile sprinkled with sea salt (burnt caramel toffee, sesame and chile).  

I really wanted to like the place, but I expected so much more and in the end, I was left feeling..."blah."  I'm sorry Yield that you're only getting two (2) stars from me.  I don't think I'll be back again either.
author: Celeste M.

description:
I love this place. It's a perfect first date or go-out-for-drinks-with-people-you-don't-really-know-very-well place, because it's classy but not obnoxiously pretentious. It's cool and modern and hip, but also sorta warm and friendly. Nobody's trying too hard, they just seem sincere. Also, I'm not really much of a bar person, but this place was nice because of the lighting and because it's not too loud. It's sorta somewhere between restaurant and bar, and I don't know of too many other places that fill that much-needed niche. 

The flatbreads are tasty and the wine selection is all organic. I'm not much of a wine connoisseur, so I don't really feel qualified to judge it on its selection, but I know I've enjoyed all the wines I've tried there, and the one time I went there with a total wine snob, he didn't seem appalled by the selection, so I take that as a good sign.
author: Melinda K.

description:
I love me a good wine bar- and this one was no exception.

Located on 3rd in the Dogpatch, Yield is nestled along a very unpopulated street. There is literally nothing around it and if you weren't looking for it you would drive right past it. It is however just around the corner from one of the best breakfast places called "Just for You Cafe."

When you walk in there is a small bar and the rest of the main room is filled with leather chairs and a few "trunks" to sit on. The next room has abut 4 or 5 tables; the rooms are both very dark.

I go back and forth between whites and reds but this time I tried a few of the whites and a glass of their sparkling wine.

First up was the Gamble Vineyards Sauvignon Blanc- SO light and not sweet- it was pretty good. You can do either a 2oz, 6oz or a full glass. I did 2 oz tastings and then a glass of the sparkling wine.

Next up was the Chardonnay/Viognier from France- another tasting wine that wasn't too heavy or oaky. Normally I am a fan of the more buttery chards but this one was light and I enjoyed it.

Next up- glass of the Pinot Blanc Reisling- I was happy with this and glad it wasn't too wine tasting. It was a nice fresh crisp glass that I enjoyed.

Now what would a wine bar be without some good food right? This place does not disappoint. Try the olives and the artichoke dip for sure. I did try the 3 fish plate that was good except the "blue fish" was too salty and not quite as good as the trout or salmon.

All in all I will visit this place again to enjoy some great food and great wine!
author: Jen S.

description:
When I first thought about what to write for this review, I struggled with what makes one wine bar better than another. They all serve wine and I have to admit I'm not sophisticated enough to know what makes a spectacular wine list. They all serve cheese. Once again, I heart all cheeses. They all offer a dim-lit lounge-y ambiance. So I guess you have to dig a bit deeper to look at the little things.

At Yield, the service was ungodly good. We could call on any of the waiters to help us. They were attentive and replenished our bread when needed. And the best part was, I barely noticed they were there! I could focus 100% of my attention on the company at hand. Their location serves them well also because it never got crowded.
author: Susan L.

description:
I cannot really comment on their food and I am not a wine drinker in the first place, but this place was so friendly and accomodating to my large party that it deserves recognition.  I came with my party after dinner for my bf's birthday.  I called the day before to ask if there is a cake cutting fee.  The guy was super friendly and told me there is but there is no fee if I wanted to bring cupcakes or cookies.  He also reserved a table for us for 9:30 when my original plan was just to walk in (did not know they took reservations).

It turned out dinner ended early and we got there at 9.  The bartender again was being so nice that he still arranged the table for us to sit.  He was very attentive and continually checked on us.  He also took our cupcakes in the back and brought it out on plates when it was time to celebrate.  As for the wines, the bf chose them and everyone seemed to enjoy them.  

Too bad I live on the other side of town.  Otherwise I would come more frequently.  Other than that when I am in the area, I would totally stop by and have a glass of wine.
author: A W.

description:
Good concept wine bar in a good location, the up-and-coming Dogpatch area.  Like others have said, very down to earth and friendly.  Our server, Duncan, was very nice and fairly knowledgeable.  

My favorite aspect of the space was the solid wood tables.  The colors are warm and earthy, although the shades of brown that were used could be better.  The wine selections were pretty good and the cheeses were yummy (Humboldt Fog - mmm).
author: ashton c.

description: Went here last night (tuesday), got there around 530 and there were only two other people in the bar. Theres understandably no corkage but the person i was with called ahead and they made an exception for us because it was his family's wine, so that was really appreciated.  The decor is minimal,  some of the leather chairs  need to be replaced but they were so comfortable I could've fallen asleep right there. We had the herb roasted potatoes, which were very yummy, and the guy brought us a syrah and a petit verdot to taste after we finished our wine, we went with the verdot which was delicious, but both were good. It was trivia night and the regulars started to come in around 7. The guy ( I cant remember his name) writes the trivia himself which is really cool! One of the employees joined our newbie team of two and we came in 5th out of 8 I believe. Service was excellent, very friendly and talkative, knowledgeable. Definitely would go back
author: Leanna C.

description:
Organizing a reunion of friends who live in the City and the East Bay when you live in another state is kind of tough, I've learned, especially when San Francisco is home but in the two years you moved away you don't know what's still open, what's new, what's long been shuttered, and what's been overrun by cockroaches but somehow is still in operation.

But thanks to Yelp I chanced upon Yield. I was looking for an interesting place I'd never been to (ie. opened up after I left), which seemed relaxing and didn't look too loud so we could all hear each other. Yield definitely seemed to fit the bill, although it also had an added bonus  - parking. I didn't want wherever we were going to meet to be a "Yo everyone! I'm back! Let's kick it after you spend an hour driving around the same block looking for a parking spot" kind of place, so the location was perfect. Also, I just wanted to see the completed T line with my own eyes, and there it was. With no T running on it.

Anyway, I'd say the atmosphere inside is great. Smallish, darkish, and comfortable. Great music and good service. I had an organic  tempranillo which was extremely smooth and a nice biodynamic pinot which complemented the olive tapenade flatbread perfectly. None of my friends who met me there knew Yield even existed before, and they all gave the place a thumbs up. We hung out there for a few hours and in that time we saw the crowds ebb and flow, but it never got too packed. Every customer still had a place to sit in either room.

Downsides include the lack of an extensive food menu (given the location is so separated from everything else), and a more extensive choice of wines (but I'll overlook this - given how many organic/biodynamic wineries actually exist), but all in all, a great discovery. Definitely recommended for folks looking to relax with a glass or two in a small, casual atmosphere.

4 stars.
author: Mr K.

description:
Great ambiance. Friendly to the neighbors. Nice range of wines.

This place is in a sweet spot of SF, the Dogpatch. The mostly organic wine selection and assortment of tapas'ish plates makes you want to linger on the couches and drink until your teeth turn red. 

The owner and bartenders are sweet and not too chatty. 

Easy access from the T line, a great place to savor the moment.
author: Miel H.

description: The venue was pretty normal. I left the waiter a 20% tip so I was disappointed to find my credit card statement that they had added an additional amount to the bill. So if you go... bring CASH.
author: Johnny L.

description:
Wow. 

Beautiful interior space with a stellar (Organic!) wine list.  The cheese platter is also excellent and easy on the wallet.  While this wine bar might be a bit off the beaten path it's well worth the effort (or the T Line!) to make it over for a taste.  

They are also huge studs for carrying my fav winery Medlock Ames on their wine list!  If they start carrying it by the glass I'll give them five stars. ;)
author: Claire C.

description:
There is nothing not to like about this place.

Great selection of  wines, continually changing to ensure variety
Friendliest bar staff - Nick and Francesca you're awesome
Interesting, delicious tapas
Reasonable prices
Friendly, fun clientele always willing to strike up a conversation 
All served in a cozy atmosphere that supports local artists
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I used to live down the street from Yield, now I live a six hour flight away.  More than any other drinking place in SF, I miss this place.  Brooklyn should be so lucky to have a Yield of our own.     

Excellent selection and excellent guidance to help you find the wines that you should be drinking.
author: Don G.

description:
Like the location, love the concept, cool interior, but would like to make the following suggestions:

- more wines by the glass
- more snacks (loved the cheeses we tasted but they need a few more accompaniments)
- re-think some of the seating

Planning more visits so will update this accordingly...
author: Mariangela S.

description:
I'm not sure what I was expecting when I dragged my friends to Yield, but I was met with a backlit, wall-to-wall shelf of wine bottles overlooking a room filled with comfy chairs, low tables, and comfy-looking-but-eventually-painful ottomans.  The space managed to accommodate my group of around 10, on a friday night, without feeling crowded, and there were other folks there besides my group.  There's another room with high tables that we didn't go into.

Enough chit chat.  Onto the good stuff.  I thought organic, sustainable, biodynamic wine would be expensive, hard to compare with "normal" wine, and impossible to buy anywhere other than this wine bar.  I was wrong.  It turns out that many "normal" vineyards (especially European ones) go about their business in a way that qualifies them as organic, biodynamic, or sustainable, and that means there are some great wines here that you might actually be able to purchase on your own.  There are also some uncommon combinations or sources that make the trip down to 3rd St. worthwhile.

One of the bartenders/owners/proprietors helped us throughout the night, kept us stocked with fresh wine glasses and carafes of water, and gave us good suggestions on wines and tasting order.  We weren't a small group, and the attentiveness of the service was noteworthy.  He said he got the idea for Yield from his years of working at Millennium.   We started with a french white blend called 'Arrogant Frog'.   Heh.  By far, the highlight of the evening was a Porter Creek Syrah that came well-recommended.

Two minor issues:

1) From when we walked in, up until midnight, the place was insanely hot and humid, to the point where the windows were entirely fogged up and several of my friends commented about how grateful they were when someone would open the front door.  I doubt such an environment is good for wine... Hopefully there are some industrial wine cellars.

2) 3rd & 22nd is far away from everything.  Unless you live right there, you'll want to drive or cab in, and keep in mind that you'll have to call a cab on the way home, since there aren't any roamers in the area.  Maybe the T-muni will change things, but I didn't see or hear a single train go by.

I'll certainly be back.  It's close enough to walk there, and after enough wine, i won't care about the walk back :)
author: Jay M.

description:
Adorable interior that is incredibly relaxing and comfortable, not fussy or overdone and completely approachable. 

The descriptions of the wines are succinct and straightforward, and there is a good variety of wines from around the world. I was impressed to see our waiter checking the newly opened bottle of wine he was pouring us a glass from, but a little horrified to see him then use it to top off half a glass from the last bottle..but overall, they keep wine traditions and serve it up in nice glasses.

While I didn't explore the culinary options, I did notice a board offering the day's cheeses, all quality (note my 9-month stint at a wine & cheese store) and easily pairable. 

I'll definately come out of my way to the dogpatch to visit Yield with a date, friends, read a book, or work on some project.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Loved it here. Thanks to all the great yelpers who recommend to go here before their dinner to Serpentine.
We got there on a Friday night around 6:30 and it was a great time. There were still plenty of places to sit. 
We both ordered 2 2oz. glasses of wine along with the Trio of Nuts and a really good Crostini with a Lentil Spread. Very good.
There were so many great wines to choose from that I have to go back to try more of them.
Service was really great, very friendly and down to earth.
author: Christine S.

description:
Yield is one of my favorite places in the city.  The wine selection is all organic and the staff is friendly and had always been accommodating, be it I'm there alone, with a date or with a group of 10.

The food plates are small, apps to be sure NOT meals.  Delish and affordable so you can try more than one.  

So why only 4 stars?  There is only one bathroom, and no real waiting area for that bathroom.  At least nothing separate from the dining area. As much as I do love this place, I don't like having to kick it looking at strangers' food while doing the pee pee dance.
author: Boots B.

description:
Really creepy.

I was there tonight with a friend, and the whole scene really creeped me out. I don't know why, but I got the most unpleasant feeling just sitting there. The people seemed nice enough, I guess, but it felt awkward, like a teenager trying too hard to make his room look cool. They have all this ultra dark ambient lighting, so dark that it's impossible to read the minimal wine list -- except for the 2000 watts of mercury vapor streaming through the big, cold plate glass window. Then they're playing this blood-drained ambient music, and it's a little too loud, like someone is worried you might not hear it and get how cool they are. 

We tried to eat, but the menu is so minimal that it's mostly an idea. One of the four things was olives with rosemary, but they were out of that. How can you run out of olives? 

After that, we sat for a few minutes waiting for wine and snacks, and I couldn't stand it anymore. The food might have been sublime -- one thing done extremely well, and all that -- but I couldn't stay there any longer. They hadn't done anything in particular wrong. I left. Sorry guys.
author: Jonathan M.

description: Great neighborhood stop. Friendly and relaxed vibe.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Eco-friendly wine. You know what? I think I CAN taste the difference. I love love love Petite Syrah and the glass I had to start was bold and full bodied, just the way I likey. Their port is also good. My friends are fans of white wines and they also enjoyed what they ordered. I wish they served more than just dips for their apetizer choices but simple is probably what they're going for their food options. I hear they change the menu every few days, which I thought was neat. The wine selections I ordered were pricey but for organic you get what you pay for. 

We went on a Saturday night and it wasn't crowded, probably because of where it's located. There's plenty of room to sit and hang. In fact there was a party of 2 that eventually grew to 12 across the way from us and the waitstaff that night didn't seem to mind that more people kept coming. Interesting art selection too- along with the decor I felt like they were going for an industrial look. Pretty chill place.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
I just wrote a (scathing) review of another nearby business so I feel I need to spread some love for the Dogpatch I call home.

Yield is lovely.  A wide selection of wines at a welcomingly wide range of prices.  It's got a cozy vibe, not stuck up at all.  Seating is comfortable and conducive to great chats.  Service is attentive, kind, but unobtrusive.
author: Katina M.

description: Relaxed neighborhood place with good small plates and great service. Reasonable glasses of wine and  interesting food options make this a perfect option for a stop on the way home. They would definitely get 5 stars if they had something to nibble on late at night, but like every other place in the neighborhood, kitchen closes relatively early ...well anything prior to 1am is early for me. It's the NY'er in me.
author: Bushra S.

description:
If you like wine, you should go here.   

my group of four took a seat in the cozy chairs by the bar.  we were greeted soon after by Chris, who suggested a great pinot noir for our differing taste buds.  we all loved it.

we ordered olives and the flat bread pizza that was also really yummy.  the pizza was the tomato,basil, cashew sauce???maybe.  i can't remember, but it was good. 

after we left, i realized i might have left my keys, so i called and got the voice mail.  while i was leaving the message, Chris picked up and asked if everything was okay.  he was so nice and told me he'd give me a call if he came across them...i later found my keys at a friend's house..duh!

i'm really glad these guys opened...it's a great mellow place in a fantastic neighborhood...mine!

cheers to yield!
author: shannon s.

description:
Update 2/06/2008:

Okay, so I usually don't Yelp like this or even talk like this but tonight at Yield, there was the loudest, most obnoxious B ever!  Everyone kept giving her dirty looks but she and her friends didn't care.  Talk about the Ugly American.

When they finally left, everyone let a sigh of relief and looked around like, "Thank God!" but...one of them tried to come back.  So, I locked the door!  Damn straight, I did.

Props to the owner that was professional when addressing them or when other customers were complaining.  I'm a patient person but when someone is so self-centered to not be considerate of others, my tolerance level quickly dissipates.  (And yes, I finally did unlock the door.  I'm not that mean:p)

Other than that, I love it here...service, wines, coziness are all A+.  Get the red wine from Chile that tastes like bell peppers.  Had 2 1/2 glasses:)

************************************

Classy Lady: Where are we??

Me: There's suppose to be a new wine bar here...somewhere...

Classy Lady: What is this place?  Are you taking me to Bayview??

Me: Okay, we'll just drive and see what it's like...There it is! 

Classy Lady: Where??

Me: Right here.  (Parking right in front.)

Inviting and warm with cozy lighting and candles.  The people that work here are great!  Helpful: recommended wines that met my preferences spot-on, friendly: genuinely and non-intrusive.  I can't say it enough but the people that work here are really nice, blond guy and pierced guy.

It would be great if they had a mirror to open up the adjoining room since we felt a little confined in the corner.  However, Classy Lady and I are quite pleased with the find and will return.  For a rainy Friday night, this was the perfect answer.

Thanks for the suggestion, Yelp.  We're going to try Serpentine next:)
author: michelle s.

description:
Great little wine bar, as others have noted.

I enjoyed all four wines I tasted (all in the name of research, naturally), and the food was good as well, though i wouldn't mind if they added a few more choices to the menu.  Vegan and vegetarian options available.  Dessert was in the form of a selection of perfect Poco Dolce chocolates, and that was exactly what i wanted to go with my Zinfandel.

Really unpretentious, with very friendly service, and a super-cool fireplace.  There is even talk of opening up on Sundays & Mondays (current opening days are Tues-Sat).  Hmm, I just might be making a detour the next time I get off the train at 22nd st station before heading home ....
author: Liz O.

description: For SF wine bars it does not have a vast a selection a la, let's say, Hotel Brion wine bar, but Yeld does provide a calmer, more upscale atmosphere.  I kind of liken it to having drinks at your country club bar.  For food, their little plates of cheeses, etc, satisfy and compliment their wine program nicely even while, perhaps, being predictable.  Small, clean, a little neighborhood spot like so many in Dogpatch, it sort of embodies the reason to head to this area of town:  under the radar, chill, and a great place to talk with friends.
author: Patrick B.

description: I have been to Yield many  times over the past few years and would normally give it a solid 4 stars.  I work at a tech company a few blocks away and have always been a happy customer. Tonight however, I was treated with such incredible rudeness that I was compelled to write. I was there with a large party (prearranged) and was seated with 2 friends at the small bar. After personally spending $50 on a bottle of wine ( generous tip included) my coworkers and I were told that we needed to vacate the bar and the stools we were sitting on for "paying customers". When I commented to "Nick", the bartender, that we were paying customers he told me that I wasn't  because we were a part of the "party" and therefor we "need to move". Apparently our party of 20 + who spent well over $500 did not, per Nick, qualify as "paying". I asked again and his response was that I could sit but as soon as a "customer" came  I had to MOVE!   I waited tables for 10 years and I understand busy but rude and disrespectful  is another story. I will never spend another dime while Nick works there and I will recommend the same to my coworkers. It's a shame because it is really a cute place that I have always enjoyed.
author: Victoria T.

description:
I love this place. Style without pretense. It's an upscale feeling yet reasonably priced wine bar in the effing dogpatch for feck's sake, and all their wine is sustainable, biodynamic, and/or organic, and REALLY GOOD.

The owner/server person is extremely knowledgeable and super friendly and has managed to load up on a pretty amazing and eclectic selection of wines. I've taken his recommendations from time to time and they haven't missed. 

And they're very keen to have this place for the long haul, being part of the community. My friend and I were the only people in the place the first time we went in and the owner's recognized me every time. (this could be because my friend brought him a giant bag of organic tomatoes and peaches to serve from his Potrero organic farm...)

It's out of the way, but don't miss this place.
author: Glen M.

description:
If a wine bar could be a dive bar, this would be it... :)

Not that there is anything wrong with that.  It is not a shabby dive, but a it simply has all the basics and little more: A bar, wine, stools, ambient music, and little eats.

Only been there once - sat at the bar - did not try any of the foods (although there were plenty of veggie options) - drank a little wine - chatted with the barkeep and the locals about he demise of the country the hope of a hew age and how we all need to support our local industry.

I'll drink to that!
author: Kingpin X.

description:
I just want to say this place is the best: Cozy and warm, great wines, good little bites, good music, nice people, good vibrations. Just comfortable and low-key, you can just melt in their sofas...and, well, there's nothing divey about it... It's cozy and has a nice neighbourhood feel to it, but that's about it as far as dive bar is concerned... Much more sophisticated than a dive bar. And great art on the walls too. I'm sure to become a regular!
We had their house red which was really good (there went my prejudice that organic wines are not as tasty...) and, no headache the day after! The cheese plate and the eggplant dip were great, can't wait to try the rest of their menu.
author: Chris D.

description:
I liked the wine selections, the way they have things worked out, limited so it's not too overwhelming.  I hands-down did not like the overly salty nuts, brie with olive baguette and everything on the menu.  Pairing wines with food should be natural and easy.  Sweets are okay too.  Not everything including chocolate should be salty.  

I will go back, but worried about the food for my tastes.  The price was right, very inexpensive and the 10 oz. half-carafe special of the day is awesome. 

~ Ms. Ali
author: A W.

description:
The great thing about the location is that there is parking everywhere, and given that its in the "up and coming" Dogpatch district, I was worried this wine bar would be too "tragically hip" for me.  I'm really more of a dive bar kinda girl.  BUT, was trying to set up some friends and we thought that would be a suitably casual, but still intimate enough for conversation to flow.

I liked this place a lot, the wine list was not extensive, but they have really good selections and apparently, all the wines are grown by organic and/or sustainable agriculture vineyards.  I also liked how you can create your own wine flights, since they have 2 oz pours as well as full glass pours.  I tried an interesting rose and a great cab franc, but their menu online is different from the menu in the bar, so I can't point out what it was.

I only wished the sommalier had talked more about the "green winery" idea behind this bar and explained the concept more to us, but it was rather difficult to address the whole group when we were such a big party.  Anyway, I would come back here again if I wanted somewhere low key to hang out and drink a nice glass or so of wine.
author: Leah S.

description:
Yum. The wines were great. I liked the bit of trivia about Syrah Palin, too. Did people actually not order the drink bc it sounded too much like the VP candidate? That's just silly. 
    Had the best glass of French wine, and their descriptions on the menu are perfect: Dusty, violet, etc. like nothing you'd see in a vanilla wine bar. 
   The plates were good; cheese plate was my fav. 
  The service was strange. He forgot a lot of our order and tried to play it off. Then he didn't want to retrieve the check, since they were closing, and asked me to bring it to him. It was fine, but a bit strange for the tip one might get on a $95 bill.
author: Molly L.

description:
True to the Yelp reviews before mine, it was a very cute and comfortable place for a glass of wine. It's in Potrero Hill, so not as nice/chic/(some may even say pretentious) as many of the other places you find in the city... But it is still very well set up so that you still feel like you are out in a nice place without feeling like you need to impress. 
The crowd was very mixed when I was there, but overall it has a very chill, down-to-earth feel. Lively atmosphere, without being too noisy or overcrowded. It really was unlike many of the wine bars I've tried in this city. Despite how established the place already was, I still felt like I had found a hidden gem that no one else knew about. 
I had the Riesling and the Pinot Noir and both were reasonably good for the price. They have a great selection of wine... wide variety without it being too overwhelming. The staff is very friendly and even warned me about some of the wines being a bit on the sweet side, etc. 
The food is not the greatest, but again, this is a wine bar. And even though it comes in very small portions, it is only five dollars a plate. I only recommend that you go to yield in a post-lunch/dinner state.
author: Guri G.

description:
Typical wine bar in an upcoming yuppie area.  The waiters were very attentive to us, which was a big plus.  Wine was decently priced at around $9 avg. per glass.  Food was mediocre at best.  
Would I go back? perhaps.
author: Michael H.

description:
Nice wine bar!  Easy to park.  I park right around the corner and the area has cleaned up a lot.  There are a few small restaurant around the corner with outside seating.  Looks cool!  Well, let's talk about the wine bar.  I went with a friend of mine who loves desert wine.   We both had a glass of cabernet and a glass of desert wine.  We dropped $40 bucks but it was disappointed.  The wine was bitter and extra sour.  I kind of whispered the bartender over and quietly told him about it because I am not the type of person who like to make a scene and affect the business.  The bartender was very polite.  He is very cool, but he poured a little sip of the wine and try it.  He then said it is a little strange but it is "still OK" to drink.  I could see it in his face.  The wine was nasty.  He had that awwwwwwwww look on his face after he tasted the wine.  
Actually, not really look for a refund (He could have done that) or give me something else just to fix my palate.  I really didn't want the desert wine but my friend insisted because he got all excited with a desert wine.  Hmmmmm...........I may not go back.
author: William F.

description:
Wine bars are a funny thing for me. They're obviously something I'm attracted to, but at the same time there are few that I like spending time at.

We stopped by Yield after another awesome dinner @ Chez Papa. We were actually on our way to the Dogpatch Saloon but we veered into this spot next door. They have a nice, fancy interior and I kind of liked our little stools set around a wooden table. The wine list was OK, organized well but missing anything I really wanted to try. Then I noticed it at the bottom: "All of our wines or Organic or Bio-Dynamically Produced." My experience with organic wines has been, well, bad, so my heart sunk a bit when I read that. They did however have a Chardonnay from China on the menu so I figured it *had* to be good since they went out of their way to taste it, order it, and bravely put it on their menu

But it wasn't. It was *terrible*. Completely undrinkable. Why would you put such a horrible wine on your menu at a wine bar? I hope the people that run this joint ask themselves that very question.

All in all we had five different wines and I got to taste a bit of all of them. The Cabernet Franc, Zinfandel, & Cava were all OK. All were watery and unbalanced. The Syrah was the best of the group. The Cava had a strong yeast flavor and was not satisfying.  Sigh. I wish this place luck, but when I don't like your wine and you're a wine bar things are tough.  

The space is very nice, the employees were friendly, and this place definitely has potential to be a great spot in the Dogpatch or I wouldn't post this review.
author: Cory G.

description:
We came here with about 15 friends for a get together and they accommodated us quite well as they don't take reservations for these type of events. They were really great and nice people.

The wines are nice and reasonably priced. I didn't think they were fantastic but were good and a very well rounded offering. I started with the Reisling and then jumped to the Malbec. The Malbec was my favorite on the menu. I also tasted the Zin, Syrah, Muscadet and others. I'm a big Zin & Petite Syrah fan but their Zin didn't do it for me.

Other stuff. Yield is a great place to sit around and have conversations with friends and sip fine wine. I agree the service is flawless-just there when you need it. The food menu is yummy, innovative & fresh (orange rinds and infused into my olives--cool!) Music selection was OK yet appropriate for the venue

I'm still waiting for a place in SF that is as fabulous as Eno in Chicago (One is said to be coming to Union Square) that has tons of amazing cheese, chocolate and wine. Now that is heaven! But more of Yield's atmosphere. (Yield please bring us more cheese and chocolate!)

All said, I would go to Yield again.
author: Karlyn N.

description:
This relatively new addition to the slowly growing Dogpatch neighborhood  is treated like the first lichen on rocks in the Arctic: people are afraid to tread on it for fear that it may be the beginning of something special. Fortunately, this wine bar stands up on its own right. 

The wine list features about 40 wines. Since I am no sommelier, I appreciate the notes the menu provides on each wine. Wine bars that aren't pretentious about their wine are far more enjoyable for us novices.

The snacks here are yummy. They only have 4 or so items on the menu but they are all tasty. I've tried the cheese plate and the flat bread and both have made fine companions to the wine.

The space this bar occupies is an open, two room affair. It's either a converted warehouse, or more likely designed to look like a converted warehouse like everything else south of Market these days. As such, it can be very noisy.
author: Keith C.

description: I don't know why this place has all this buzz.  The wine selection is not good for a wine bar, mediocre at best and the staff is not knowledgeable.  Also the beer selection is even worse than the wine selection.  It also fees dirty in there.
author: SF L.

description:
I have only written one other review, so that should tell you: I mean business when I say that Yield is my new favorite place and I'm thinking about naming my next baby after them.

Here's the story:

I was looking for the perfect place to throw a surprise party for my husband. I wanted to pretty much take over the place, but I didn't want to rent it out; I wanted food, but I didn't want a sit-down meal; I wanted drinks, but I didn't want a pub; and I didn't want to pay a bazillion dollars. 

Someone suggested Yield. Then someone else did. Then I saw all the good reviews on Yelp, so I emailed them. Chris got back to me right away and said, basically, "Let us take care of you." But not in a creepy way. In a good way. We exchanged an email, then he picked up the phone and called me! That's right - HE CALLED ME! None of that silly back-and-forth email business. He just picked up the phone. We worked out a great deal on plenty of food for 20 guests, and he offered to cut and serve the cake I was planning on bringing. I knew it was going to be good.

When we showed up on the big night, Nick was there - and he was just as great as Chris! In fact, Nick doted on us all night! And not in a creepy way! He kept checking in with me, to make sure everything was going well. He kept the delicious food coming out at perfectly timed intervals. He made suggestions for how to lower the cost of our drinks a bit (just buy the bottle! it's way cheaper!). And, the piece de resistance - he went out and bought candles for the cake! How nice is that?!

I could go on and on about how all our friends loved this place, how amazing the food was, how nice the people were, how great the space was, how vast the bathroom is...all that. But I won't.

You should throw your birthday party at Yield.
author: Michele G.

description:
I would give it 2.5 if I could just because Chris the owner is so nice.

Atmosphere:  comfy, cozy, great for friends or a date

Flat breads and cheese plates:  well selected, flavorful - amazing

Wines:  here is where the trouble begins - they focus on organic - fine - but at the cost of having really good wines on their list.  It is unfortunate.  On a recent evening we ordered 12 different wines by the glass from sparkling to white and red and NONE of them were anything any of us would ever order again or order by the bottle....UNDERWHELMING.

We are really bummed as we like the place - but I go to a wine bar for the WINE above all and again and again they fall short here - the thing is too that really wine is not a pesticide heavy industry and the organic label not THAT meaningful with wine - I wish they would reconsider and go for complexity and character in wines rather than the organic label - and I shop only local and organic in my diet ......

.......but please leave me my wine.......In the end though it is walking distance I would rather go where I am going to find something I know I will enjoy drinking.
author: Mylea C.

description:
Just a short line or two to say that we dropped by recently for a glass and a nibble ,the frys. The list is well chosen and reasonably priced.The atmosphere is downright neighborly/friendly. Other than hitting it on trivia night, not a fan of 'bar games', it is worth checking out if you are in the neighborhood.
I would return more frequently if I lived closer.
author: Lou S.

description: The trivia BAR moderator takes his job too seriously. My table was spending 100s of dollars  during TRIVIA night and on more than one occasion the bar host rudely admonished  us for checking our phones and questioning the logic behind one of the answers to the questions.  It a game and the bar seems to take it to a level where they are forgetting that there are paying customers trying to have a good time.  Isn't that the point .  Apparently the BAR guy Nick needs to evaluate his priorities and maybe get some training on business 101 and customer service.  Or go apply for Pat Sajack or Alex Trebecks job because he obviously is misplaced and detrimental to yield' bottom line objective unless that objective is to lose customers which in that case they doing just fine.   I will never go there again.
author: AM S.

description:
Sweet little spot in Dogpatch.  I love the casual community seating - you could go with a big group or just a date and feel comfortable.  Last time I was there my friend was chatting up our server(?)/bartender(?)/wine porer(?) for so long that I thought they knew each other. But no, they're just friendly folks.  

Nice selection of organic and biodynamic wines too- They call themselves the first "green wine bar" in SF.  

It's near the 22nd street Caltrain stop which is awesome for me since I commute from the peninsula.  (Admittedly the station is a bit sketchy late at night)
author: Kate T.

description:
Stopped by on rainy Friday at 9 or so, after open studios.  

Sat in the window and had a few great glasses with a few friends. The wine really is over the top good for organic, I was expecting to be underwhelmed, and I was blown away.

The staff is easy on the eyes, well, at least our server was, though he lost a point for forgetting our food order.  Funny how the sexy ones can get away with that....
author: Ken p.

description: Cute atmosphere and ambiance.  Small and quaint. Great people work there. The wines are excellent. Food is yummy. Prices are reasonable.  Tons of parking available....and all this is only a few blocks away from our house. Absolutely perfect.
author: Sharon T.

description:
GREAT wine bar. It doesn't hurt that I walked into District and walked out (so not the scene for a casual hang at a wine bar).
Super friendly service, nice wine, great atmosphere. Didn't have any snacks (they were out of the flatbreads when I went) but would definitely go back. Really cozy, really casual. Makes me want to move to dogpatch from SOMA.
author: Margie L.

description: Met the gals here for HH on a Thursday.  Had a cozy little sitting area with a couple half bottles on special.  Good wines.  Bonus:  Good french fries!
author: Mabelle A.

description:
My husband introduced me to this place, and I immediately loved it. The space is very appealing to me - intimate lounge-like with a warm / inviting industrial feel - if that makes any sense. Big dark wood block coffee tables, gently worn club chairs, vintage chairs and sofas --- all sitting quite nicely on a painted pavement floor. 

Interesting wine list that definitely kept me reading. I finally settled on a  2005 Forrest Estate Sauvignon Blanc from Marlborough, New Zealand - very clean, crisp, and citrusy with grapefruit. My husband had a 2004 Zind Humbrecht Pinot Blanc which was very nice and also went perfectly with our menu selection of Madara Manchego, Pierre Robert Triple Cream, Seuvre et Belle goat, and rosemary toasted almonds. And, I love how the Yield guys come sit with you when you order or have questions - it's like talking to a friend. Nice touch. This modest and unpretentious wine bar is a gem.

Oh and ... some guy, who appeared to be hosting something, was speaking to a group of about 6 people and asked, "Do you guys know about Yelp?" Perhaps another Yelp evangelist.
author: Lizelle G.

description:
Great great place!  Totally a diamond in the rough.  I've driven past here plenty of times and never noticed it.  3rd Street near Hunters Point?  Definitely a step in the right direction.

Very classy with a relaxing atmosphere.  I brought a friend here since she had a really tough week and knew that a glass of wine and sofas would definitely be in her best interest.  Or is it mine?  No matter  ;-)  It was great!

The service was definitely top-notch and truly a classy place.  Parking might be an issue and some people might get nervous leaving at night.  I think they should offer more food on their menu.  The one thing my friend wanted and they had run out.  Uh, it was only 7:30pm...  We were much more hungry anyway than the little finger-food they had...  So it was off to find a good sushi place..

Definitely a place to come and enjoy the good wine selection and atmosphere.  It doesn't get so loud that you have a hard time keeping a conversation.

Go go go!
author: R G.

description:
This is quickly becoming our (my husband and I) favorite spot for "date night."  We usually head out for dinner elsewhere and come here to extend our evening -- just long enough to be SURE the 'sitter has put both kids to sleep before we head home.  

The service is prompt and friendly.  They have a great selection of Organic wines: red, white, ports.  Something for everyone.  Great music.  

A great spot to go cuddle with someone or a small group of close friends.  No I don't mean cuddle in that way -- I meant in the Mom and Dad with 2 Toddlers kind of way....
author: Spicy T.

description:
