Ahh, Yield.  When we first rolled by this amazing wine bar, I thought it was closed because it looked so dark on the inside.  But lo and behold it was open for business and has left it's mark on me.  When I first saw organic wine, I thought Yeach!, but I must prostrate my self in front of the Yield Wine Bar holiest of holy wine wisdom in venerated respect.  Great wine place to get together with friends.  

They are knowledgeable and even have some snacks to soak up some of that liquid loveliness.  The music isn't so loud that you can't talk and it isn't packed like some other wine bars.  If you don't like wine, this probably isn't the place for you, because that is about the only type of drink they have here besides water.  I heart Yield....
author: Chris W J.

description:
We love Yield!  Only been there once, but we intend to go back!  We wish Yield moved closer to the Ocean Beach side of SF so we maybe could frequent more often.  However, it is worth the journey over there.  We went with friends, loved the "green" atmosphere, delicious crispy thin pizzas, cheese plate and all the jammy wine we could find!  All of their recomendations were spot on.  We could not get over one of the wines that we had there, and contacted the owners to get more information about it and they not only told us what that wine was, but how to get it!  The owners are warm, friendly and inviting people!
We'll be back for sure!
author: Lori T.

description: This place is nice the decor is beautiful it nice to relax an enjoyed a few glasses of wine. The have a fantastic selection of wind, the bartender is very helpful on the selection of there wine. Come on in an enjoyed a glass our two
author: Travis S.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to go for a good glass of wine.  It is truly a wonderful, small, cozy neighborhood kind of place.  I don't even live in the area but make a special trip to go there when I can.

The space is small and divided into two rooms.  The front room has a small bar and several couches and low stools.  The other room has tall tables for larger groups.  The wine list is great and covers many countries with all the wines being from organic, biodynamic or sustainable wineries.  The staff is very knowledgeable about the wines and offer great recommendations.  Plus the pours are very generous!

Great place to go with a small group of friends where you can actually have a conversation and enjoy some great wine.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Was here briefly after visiting Crushpad across the street.  Very nice wine list, all organic and/or biodynamic wines.  Nice cheese list.  Great, casual atmosphere.  And nuts to die for - sweet/herbal mix - they're addictive.

Hope to come back and try more on the menu and wine list.
author: Ron W.

description: We love good wine and this bar has a very large selection of red and white wine it nice to relax and have a good conversation and enjoy a nice wine after a hard day at work.
author: Barbara S.

description:
I was rolling with my girl Sally K. on her birthday here, and we had a great time.  

The best part about this place was: The Crowd. I have never said that about another establishment in San Francisco.  Ecectic and well dressed, but not obnoxious and poser.  Almost like a New York hot spot, BUT without the arrogance. 

Oh yeah and the wine was good too.  It's a small space so you might want to call ahead to make sure you can get a seat before you come all the way there (it's very far out there).
author: Moi S.

description:
I've come here about 4 or 5 times and had a fantastic experience. Here's why:

1) Parking. It's everywhere. There's something to be said about not having to circle for 20 minutes.
2) Interior. It's got the understated glamor of Bourbon and Branch mixed with the romantic noir of Hotel Biron
3) Plenty of space. I've never been there when it's full. It's always comfortably active, and you don't have to fall over other people to get a table.
4) Wines with purpose. I don't know any of the wines on the list, but they're all grown bio-dynamically. Drinking wine here feels like driving a prius up 101 in the carpool lane during rush hour. Ok, maybe not, but it still means you get a very interesting list of wines.
5) The Chocolate plate. My god, the chocolate plate. Try the Aztec Chile, the sesame, and... the burnt caramel toffee.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I walked into Yield an hour and half late to find my friend at the bar well on her way to falling off her stool (She loved the place). I sat at the bar with her and enjoyed the totally neighborhoody feel of the joint. They had quite a bit of people working the night that I was there (ordering was easy and quick), and the owner Chris was out and about talking the wine game. I had a couple different glasses at 6-8$ and my wasted friend paid for it all (even better!). We also tried the cheese plate which was good, although they had some other items which were sold out that I have been told are better. Guess I'll have to go back another time to check it out!

Bottomline: Cool little joint, especially if you live in the hood or around Potrero Hill.
author: Matt C.

description: foods always good... its got a great relaxed vibe going on! Great place to kick back and chill with good company!
author: S R.

description:
Great local bar in the Dogpatch area!

-cozy atmosphere
-great wine selection
-yummy flatbreads and cheeses
-awesome service by bartender and staff
author: Christian S.

description:
I love this neighborhood and I love this place. 

The interior is designed well and comfortable. It satisfies my many moody moments. 

The staff is so friendly, knowledgeable, and approachable. It's always comforting to see Chris there. He's sweet and cute and I trust his recommendations. 

The menu is organized in just the right way...from lightest to fullest. And the tasting notes are concise. I've always had an easy time narrowing my choices down, and I never feel overwhelmed.
author: S. P.

description:
I LOVE this place! It's across the street from my art studio and it's the perfect place to meet a friend and catch up with a glass of carefully chosen wine and some tasty nibbles after painting all day. I prefer it when it's not so busy, but at the same time I am happy to see them do well, so I don't wish slow nights on them. 

The lighting, music, artwork, and sweetness of the owners are all just right. Great spot!
author: Annie G.

description:
Love the wine and the appetizers.

Staff is really helpful and friendly. Neighborhood gem!

Cheese plate is amazing.. go.
author: Art A.

description: Yield is the perfect neighborhood wine bar: genuinely nice staff who treat you like a friend when you walk in the door & who make smart wine/food pairing suggestions, a great interesting wine list, comfortable ambiance, and delicious small plates. Added bonus - their wines are organic/biodynamic/sustainable.
author: P K.

description:
When I hear the words "wine bar" often something sort of stuffy and pretentious comes to mind.  Yield is very much the opposite.  Super friendly staff, really delicious food and most importantly, the wine is absolutely beautiful. 

I wish I would have ventured further into both the wine and food menus.  I had the grenache blanc and sauvignon blanc for wine and for food, the sunchoke dip and cod cake sandwiches. All wonderful.  It was easy to get to via the N-judah and T-third st.
author: jen b.

description: Holy monkey fuzz. This is one of the best secret wine bars in the city. The guys that run it always have a great selection of wine, and if you don't know your wines don't worry they won't make fun of you and love talking about their wine selection in easy to understand terms. The food dishes are small, tasty and affordable. A great place to hit up when your in the dogpatch.
author: Atom H.

description:
I've been there about four times. Had a blast each time.

The cheese plates are great and the owner and service is wonderful.

Plus it's near some great food at Hard Knox.

Great place to unwind and chill without being pretentious.

It's all about the Malbec for me.
author: Eugene L.

description:
My only apprehension in writing this review is that I don't want to share it.  I loved that we could sit down when we walked in.  I love that we were close enough to chat with people around us, but could still keep our own conversation to ourselves. 
Food rocked, wine selection rocked, service rocked.
And they were super nice when I shattered a wine glass when trying to scavenge the last morsel of amazing flat bread pizza off the plate.
I would totally come back here- it might finally be a reason to try out the 3rd street line, which runs right past it.
author: Alisha A.

description:
Hmmm...the wine DOES go well with the chicken...

We've been going to this place since it opened, conveniently 4 blocks from our pad.  Always a great organice, biodynamic wine list.  Chris the owner is very knowledgeable.  All the staff are really nice too.  This is the easy, kick back, perfectly loungy spot for a couple of friends or big-*ss group.  Little fire place.  Definitely the perfect atmosphere when you are looking for a low-pro evening.  The lack of (even background) beats keeps this place a strict wine bar and not the pre-party spot that the decor seems to lend itself too.  But, that's no knock, just laying it out.  This is a great place and good time for wine lovers.  (Only thing keeping this from being a full 5 stars for me, the thing that would make this spot the complete DL spot, is lack of even mild beats.  Sorry, still in my beat-phase!)  Love you Yield!
author: Isa L.

description:
welcome to the dogpatch, where i see no dogs nor patches.

upon entering yield i met with what seemed to be a very overzealous owner/waiter. he looked like the little brother to my high school physics teacher, but i didn't hold that against him.

yield prides themselves on delivering wines that are organically grown. or made from organic grapes. or something that makes tree huggers in sf with beards and recycle bins happy.

now the important part: the wine.

it wasn't bad! i bought a bottle of the burgundy which was very fruity and light, yet had a very earthy flavor. not typical, but enjoyable.

i'd go back.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I love Yield. Let me say it again, I love Yield!

I've been three times so far, and each time it's been terrific. It's warm, cozy, friendly and with a phenomenal wine list. The owner Chris is fun and always recommends a great glass of wine to me. And I always seem to meet friendly and fun people there.

Combined with dinner across the street at Serpentine, Yield is the perfect place to spend an evening in SF drinking great wine.
author: Nissa A.

description: Nice, laid back neighborhood wine bar, specializing in organic and biodynamic wines.  Note - when they say they only have small plates, they mean it.  Don't go hungry.  That having been said, the small plates were tasty and only $5 each.
author: B. Y.

description:
Why I really like Yield:
1. Great wines (although they have a Palin Syrah apparently, which is not selling well. Ha!)
2. Nice staff - always ready with recommendations
3. Beautiful interiors with comfy, loungey chairs - if you go earlier in the day when it's still bright, it's awesome to sit next to those giant windows, sip on some wine, and be mesmerized by the traffic on 3rd St
4. REALLY nice staff - we had a small surprise gathering for my sis here (without really calling Yield to warn them ahead of time, shame on us) and the staff was so gracious about us bringing in a cake and providing us with plenty of plates and forks. 
5. Cool fireplace (?) - you have to see it to know what I mean. It's like a little box in the wall, about torso height, with a little slot on top. And there's blue flame coming out of it. So neat!!
6. Did I mention the people there are super nice??
author: Angi C.

description: Cool place, chill atmosphere.  I used to come here a lot when I worked up at Mission Bay.  It's a good place to enjoy a glass of wine after work.  They have a good selection of wines, and the staff is very knowledgeable about each one. They also have pretty good food...small plate style, great for sharing.  If you're in the area, check it out!
author: Sonal P.

description:
Remarkably good/interesting/varied selection of wines by the glass, and they rotate frequently. In the past year the food has really gone up a notch too, from "a few good snacks" to great small dishes.

I've gone here many times.
author: Max D.

description: Bartenders are very knowledgeable on the wine. Their description is very spot on. I would come here for a relaxing night to chill with friends. They have a good staff.
author: Helen L.

description:
Your neighborhood wine bar.

Low key, mellow, down to earth.  This place combines great wine with an unpretentious atmosphere.  Add reasonable prices and the mix is a winner.

They have a good selection of organic, biodynamic, and sustainable wines.  Their food menu is limited but tasty.  Try their flatbreads and cheese plate.  Don't come here for a meal or you'll leave hungry.

A great place for before or after dinner drinks.
author: L Y.

description:
Yield is fine. It's everything you want your wine bar to be.  It's cozy and dark, and they've got lots of wines. Isn't that what people want, to snuggle up by the fire with a glass of expensive wine? Wait, why did you go to the Dogpatch for a wine bar? Do you work on 3rd Street? Did you just get off work? If so, you probably work in a warehouse, so why didn't you just grab a brew at the Dogpatch Saloon? I'll be honest, I don't understand wine bars, and after working a full day at a winery, the last thing I want to do is swirl wine. So disregard everything I've said.

Wait, I know why you went to the Dogpatch, because it's way better than the Marina, right. Right.
author: Daniella C.

description:
If you are looking for a mellow, chill place to catch up with a friend(s) over wine, Yield is a great choice.  

I hadn't hung out with my friend Kristy in nearly a year (shameful!) so we went here last night and enjoyed quite a few interesting wines.  When we first arrived at 5:45 it was pretty empty, just us and two women across the room.  By the time we left at 8:30 it was much busier.  The two men and the cute dog working last night kept the wine and nibbles coming quite well despite the crowd.  When we ordered a bottle we were told that they had just sold the last one.  But, they were quick to offer a similar wine as a replacement.  We tremendously enjoyed it.

This is definitely a great place to enjoy intimate conversation and wine!!
author: Jeff P.

description:
This place could be the greatest wine bar in the history of wine bars, but it is not.

I cannot declare it as the greatest because every time I go there, they never have a brut rose.
author: Godzilla C.

description: Yield took a few years to grow on me but it has. The funky decor and location are a huge factor in my yielding to Yield and the bar food is the other. The wines were the sticking point but over the years I think I've started to get it. The importance of sustainable growing, the fact that a bio-dynamic wine or even an organic one is going to be a little different from a what I may ordinarily be looking for etc. I am guessing that the focus on California wines has to do with the sustainable local thing. Still, every once in a while I wish I could have a Marlborough Savignon Blanc with their amazing cheese stuffed dates and look out at the industrial Third Street scene. Great place.
author: Margaret G.

description: This is one of the cutest wine bars in the city. I love small local places. The owners are super nice and always very attentive and knowledgeable. I love coming here. Their menu is also quite extensive for a wine bar and they have a nice cheese selection as well. Love this place!
author: Agnetha M.

description:
Yield is the kind of place that you want to tell everyone about because it's so great but you don't really want them to know about because it's so great. But because it's all over Yelp I'm probably too late.

I've been here twice once with kids (babies) and once without and both times the owner and staff were extremely helpful -- if not a bit overworked -- and readily available for suggestions. I'm not encouraging anyone to bring kids here but I didn't feel unwanted when I did and I appreciate that. Also the neighborhood is overdue for something sophisticated and special like Yield.
author: Roger G.

description:
Modern and upscale yet cozy, unpretentious, and friendly. Great place to meet for a glass or two and a snack before dinner. The wine, food, decor, and staff are all excellent.

My only, ONLY complaint is that they really need to hire more staff to help out on the busy nights. I know they are just starting out, but on a recent Friday we waited almost an hour to get the flatbread we ordered as a snack, and almost twenty minutes for a third glass of wine. My friend and I were sympathetic; we could see the three staff members scurrying around, and they were always really friendly and apologetic, but we were there for an hour longer than we wanted to be.
author: Holly A.

description:
I was introduced to Yield quite by accident. A friend who works in the area suggested we meet there for a drink. I was pleasantly surprised to find this oasis in a rather barren neighborhood.

The space is small, cozy and minimalist inside with nice brown hues with soft seats and solid wooden tables in the main room and high tables and stools in the side room.

This is a wine bar so don't expect beer or mixed drinks. The wine list is impressive, with many local, organic wineries. The staff have always been extremely friendly, professional and willing to talk to you about wine, and make suggestions.

The wine flights are a nice way to explore new wines without making a whole glass commitment.

The snacks are also very well done - from the flats (small, thin pizzas), olives, or cheese plates. Everything will go well with your wine. I also like this bar because it is not too loud - you will actually be able to hear your friends without having to shout.  The crowd is local, mellow and friendly.
author: Spoon G.

description:
Went here on a Wednesday night and it was off and on crowded. To be quick and simple, good wine, good cheese, possibly the best flatbread pizzetta type thing I've ever had.

One suggestion... go for the bottle if you think you're gonna have a few glasses.
author: ShaColby J.

description: Coming from Pittsburg I'm not the biggest wine person and I could give a shit about my carbon footprint. That being said I really enjoyed this place and how they approach wine. Often times wine people and wine stores spend a lot of time staring in the mirror. This place gives you a fair look at things and gives you some ground. I was always told people who know dont say and people that say dont know. They tell you about wine but give you the space to ask questions without sounding like pretentious losers.
author: Tony T.

description:
Yield is quite an accomplishment.  I have lived in the Dogpatch area for six years.  For six years I've enjoyed watching it change.  Yield has been an excellent addition to our small-but-growing list of local shops and eateries in the area.  They serve a nice variety of wines - all biodynamically produced.  Equally fantastic is their price point.

Yield is a great spot to wind down.  With casual seating among several sofas and coffee tables near the bar, Yield's atmosphere is comfortable and inviting.  Most of the time it's quite easy to snag a seat in the main room.  However, as Yield's popularity has grown, seating has become limited.  Having said that, I enjoy Yield's intimate appointments.

I give it four stars because I really enjoy catching up with friends in the neighborhood for a glass (bottle) of wine and some of those delicious chocolates.  Having such a space in this neighborhood is simply fantastic.
author: Jason C.

description:
I visited Yield yesterday evening with a couple of friends.  The moment we walked in, we knew it was right up our alley.  Small and intimate, with several seating areas of long, low to the ground tables, surrounded by lush leather chairs and stools.  And we were greeted enthusiastically by the bartender, which is always nice.

He brought us water and the wine lists.  I instantly chatted him up to see what he would recommend other than what originally caught my eye.  He told me the wine I was looking at had been the most popular lately, which is great, but I was really looking for some information on flavors of other wines.

Regardless, my selection was generously poured and delicious.  The $9 price was awesome too.

We showed up before 5:30, and by the time we left around 7:00 the place was hoppin.  It maintained the intimacy, but the noise gradually increased as more and more people came in (duh).  

It's a very unpretentious place, which is a nice change from most wine bars.  I will definitely return for drinks after work, and I can't wait to try the food next time!
author: brittany z.

description: Its a fun spot for a nightcap, with a nice selection of wines in a cozy atmosphere. Their tapas like $5 menu is fun. We had some amazing stuffed dates. I can't wait to go back. Our waiter/bartender Nic was great.
author: Mark F.

description:
I love yield! Finally the Dog Patch has a place I want to walk to. Okay, the place is small, but very comfortable. I go there quite often with groups of up to about 5 people and we are always able to find a place to sit. The service is great because it is mostly staffed by the owners who are very friendly. The selection of wine is not huge but it is very well thought out and there is a twist. All of the wines featured on their rotating wine list are environmentally friendly -- they are made from grapes that are farmed organically and biodynamically! 

They also serve quite little sides of cheese and bread etc so you have something to munch on while you are in there. The people are friendly and it has become a favorite meeting spot for many.
author: kole h.

description: I love this place!  I have been there twice and felt extremely welcome by the owner and staff.  Great choices of wine, and yummy appetizers.  I shared an eggplant tartine and a spinach dip with Parmesan crust with a friend, and would order it again in a heartbeat.  Great place to go to after work to wind down.  Love it!!
author: Ana M.

description:
I feel like I should mention that this review is based solely on the wine and service. I did not get to try any of the food this time around.

My friend was celebrating her birthday and decided to meet here. I'm a red wine type of girl, and the fact that they had a Pinot Noir AND two Syrah choices made my night. Most of the time, wine lists seem to overlook these two types in favor of Cabs (which are fine), Merlots, and Zins (which I am not a fan of). We ordered a bottle of the RDLR Syrah from Mendocino - very nice wine with hints of "smoked pomegranate and leather." And for $36, it didn't break the bank. Lovely.

What I was really impressed with was the service. There were at least two guys circling the area - picking up empty wine glasses, checking water levels (they gave us our own glass water bottle so we could refill as needed) and making sure that we were all having a good time. At no point did we have to go flag someone down. It seems like a lot of times, small places tend to understaff - especially in remote places like where this was located. Both guys were awesome and we had no complaints.

The only negative is that we were sitting next to a little fire "shelf" which made our eyes water if we stood too close to it. Great for keeping the chill out, not so great for my non-waterproof mascara.

If you're looking for a place with good energy and great wine, this is the place.
author: Marie K.

description: I'd like to thank my lovely co-workers for treating me here after work. Dogpatch is one of my favorite little districts in the City with big tastes! Looking to get away from noisy downtown dives? Yield Wine Bar has cool ambiance, terrific sustainable wines (list rotates weekly), and good bites- all with very friendly service. A must-have item is their Sunchoke Parmesan Dip with Toasted Pinenuts.
author: Leroid D.

description:
Yield Wine Bar is a superlative experience in the fun and invigorating Dog Patch Area!  Brett the host is highly articulate about the wine list and graciously suits you to a wine of your palate.  One can sip, taste cheese and engage in witty conversation among friends.  
Try one of Brett's recommendations and feel transported to the ambience of somewhere very out of the ordinary!
author: yvonne c.

description:
The wine was delicious.  Although, Boone's Strawberry Hill is my all time favorite "wine" so please take my opinion with a large grain of salt.  Or consider me an expert 'cause I know you be lovin' some Boones too!  Don't lie!  Nothing says, "I'm 15 and passed out in my neighbor's basement possibly being fondled against my will" like any member of the Boone's family of "wines".  Boone's "wines" are the non-ironic 40's of middle class suburban white kids...we used to buy them with our fake ID's and then listen to Coolio in our parent's beamers.  Hardcore.  Point is, my taste in wine might be considered really, really good.  Or juvenile.  Whatevs.

What I'm really here to talk about is the true are of my expertise:  Vegan Food of the Delicious Variety.  The vegan flat bread I consumed was something involving cashew cream and truffle oil and other such fancy things and i swear, it tasted meaty and cheesy at the same time.  THAT FLAT BREAD WAS MY JAM, YO!  The salad without pancetta was also DELICIOUS...spinach and raisins and all manners of delight for the tongue.  Clearly the chefs here knows what they are doing in the vegan food department (I think the former Millennium wine guy is the owner?) and so it is with this claim that I strongly urge Yield to go 100% VEGAN IN THE SNACKS DEPARTMENT!  Obviously it is your true calling so forget these other fools and FOLLOW YOUR VEGAN HEART!  IF THIS DEMAND CANNOT BE MET, I WILL BE FORCED TO BE VERY SAD AND ALSO, ASK FOR AT LEAST ONE VEGAN DESSERT.   Because there were no desserty options for me, I had to bring and consume massive amounts of my own candy.  I would not have over indulged to the point of sickness if a dessert of a reasonable portion size were on the menu.  Please, for my health (and yours?), consider this.  

And finally, the reasons you should ask me out on a date are as follows:  I am very demanding with unreasonable requests, I have no self control, and I have one foot that is significantly larger than the other due to a freaky and, as of yet, unexplained disorder.   CALL ME!
author: Laura B.

description:
i love this wine bar.  very chill. not fancy, yet fully welcoming and cozy, a certain je ne sais quoi and with steamy windows on a rainy night.  they serve all vegan and organic wine, so you can indulge and feel good that you're supporting the good people.  we tried a variety of the whites, which were all really delicious.  

its definitely somewhere you can take someone, and be like, yeah, just this little place, no big deal....but its actually a bit of a flirt.
author: Liz S.

description: If Yield were a man, I would totally put out for him. Right on the leather couches. As long as that Tempranillo kept flowing and he hand-fed me from the three-cheese plate.
author: Gretchen T.

description: The wines here are amazing, and their descriptions of the wines are very accurate.  A lot of yelpers complain there's no parking - I can't verify or disagree with that because I took the Muni which stops a block away - very convenient.  The food was pretty good for being $5 a plate and paired well with the wines.  This is a great place for catchup up with friends.
author: Vida H.

description:
Y is for Yes and for Yield and for Yay! I'm crushing hardcore on this sexy little guy over in the dogpatch. My guy took my boobs and I to Yield last night and man was it hard to get us out of there.  We liked it so much there that we decided to call our friends and tell them to come join us. They did. It was a whole Autumn-and-Eli party in there. Our people liked the place just as much as we did. We went through two glasses, three bottles, and a couple of bowls of delicious rosemary almonds and we were delighted with all. The care that has gone into the wine list is touching. They offer only Organic, Biodynamic, and/or Sustainable wines and all at reasonable prices. Ladies, did I mention there's a chocolate plate available?
The guys running the place are adorable, knowledgeable, and very friendly. The crowd was almost nonexistent, which is the reason I am urging you all to head over to Yield. This is definitely a place we want staying open. 
The interior is masculine, with solid wood-block tables and low-slung overstuffed leather and suede seats. The tables are narrow and low, allowing for audible conversation with your drinking companions.
There is an additional room with small bar tables, candles all over the place, and a kind of romantic vibe. 
We loved it and you will too. But if you're hungry, order a cheese plate or flatbread from the kitchen early- I think the kitchen closes around 10 and there is no place in that hood that you want to be eating at 11 p.m.
author: Autumn K.

description: The wine selection is pretty good!  I found the food menu on the chalkboard really cute and charming.  After ordering a couple of the items (all 3 cheese selections) and the calamari - I understood why they were only $5 each.... the portions are incredibly small... I felt like an ogre not having enough food.  The pieces were actually cut in SMALL pieces.  It also didn't have much flavor... the aioli that came with it was completely bland.  But I get it, it's a wine bar, not a restaurant.  The food is mediocre, but the wine is yums.
author: Betty T.

description: Went to Yield for the first time last night, and walked away wanting to go back again really soon. Although the location is a bit inconvenient if you're used to taking cabs everywhere, Yield is definitely worth the drive. Parking is really easy, and once inside you're surrounded by a warm ambient light and cozy atmosphere -- perfect for enjoying a good glass of wine. Bonus points for pouring good organic and biodynamic wine... not always an easy feat.
author: Chris B.

description: Welcomed addition to the wine bars in San Francisco. My friends and I went here the other night and really enjoyed ourselves. Chris who is one of the owners greeted us when we arrived and made us feel at home the whole time we were there. They have great selection of wine and a few cheese plates, all affordably priced. We had a few $25 bottles of Lavradores Douro Temparillo. Plenty of seating that accomodated our group as it grew throughout the evening. Perfect place to go have some wine with friends and chat. Definitely go and check them out!
author: Stephanie I.

description: Wonderful find and never too packed. Great for datenight or meeting friends. Staff is so helpful. Do not order syrah with notes of leather- down right hidious.
author: SF U.

description: Stopped at Yield for a couple hours tonight after making the trek from SJ to 22nd on Caltrain. Wine was in order, and Yield was a great. Several other friends headed over from closer by, and we all had comfy chairs for relaxing and tasting good wine. Everyone in the place seemed very happy, and for good reason. We enjoyed 4 bottles of wine (try the Red & Green Zin), as well as a tasty cheese plate, split among the 6 of us. There was plenty of room for us around one of the huge wood table/benches, and the owners were very attentive. Can't wait to go back!
author: Phil K.

description: The only thing that keeps me from bestowing the elusive fifth star was the noise level. Dive bars should be loud, not wine bars. The most common word thrown around all night was "WHAT??" Other than that. I totally dig this place. I like to sit around conversing and drinking in laid back environments, which means I am starting to get old. The wine menu is great and the plates of food accompany the wine menu incredibly well. The staff was knowledgeable and guided us to some fantastic drinks. One of my favorite parts of the bar was a shelf that had fire coming out of it... I was mesmerized like a caveman. Street parking is incredibly easy to find even on a weekend night, which is not something that goes hand and hand with cool bars in the city by the bay.
author: Bucky K.

description: After reading a review in the Chron and eager to check out anything new opening in the "Dog Patch" neighborhood, I was excited to meet a friend at Yield on the '3rd street corridor.' The seating (leather-covered ottomans), the lighting and just the overall decor is warm and inviting, but also very modern. While we had to wait a bit longer than I would have liked to be approached by a waiter, we soon realized it was worth the wait. Soon after, we were presented with a couple glasses of delicious wine as well as some munchies - including a carmelized onion pizza and an incredible cheese plate (darn! we were a day too late for the figs). Next time you're looking for a warm and cozy place to catch up and feel sophisticated without feeling overwhelmed, check out Yield.
author: Deborah S.

description:
Wow!  This place is clearly head-and-shoulders above most other wine bars in the city.

What's great:
- Extremely friendly, knowledgeable staff
- Excellent and interesting wines by the glass
- A fun, casual environment
- Great nibbles (loved the spinach dip with crostini) at almost startlingly-low prices ($5/plate)
- Relatively easy parking

What's not-so-great:
- Many of the tables are communal so you may need to share with another group

Overall, this may become my go-to wine bar in SF - and that's saying a lot because there are three wine bars within five blocks of my house (Nectar, California Wine Merchant and Bin 38).  Yield blows them all away for quality and value.
author: Maggie L.

description: Great wines, great chocolates, great snacks, never overcrowded, easy access via the T train.  Amazing place for a chill night with people you want to talk to, not just look at.
author: Timothy S.

description: Like Suz, I need to check this place out again. I like my wine bars cozy, but not "large private party in smallish space" cozy. The place looked great and I'm sure it a great atmosphere on a normal night. The wine was good, but since it was so crowded we didn't really get to chat up the bartender for recommendation or anything. Still, it was tasty and I dig the whole biodynamic/organic/sustainable concept.
author: Leigh M.

description: Went here for a pre-V day dinner glass o' vino, and it was packed!  70 people.  Standing up.  As a result, service was understandably a bit slow, but the folks were so pleasant and apologetic about it that it made zero difference.  The flatbread pizza was great, and I liked the range of wines by the glass.  The space is great and understated in a cool way.  A great addition to the neighborhood.  Hooray!
author: Laurel B.

description: Starting from the first step in the door, the service was top-notch. The very cute gentleman looking after our group of 10+ was attentive, knowledgeable, and offered small tastings of wines that we were interested in but not completely sold on. Big plus - he noted I was very excited by a gewirtztraminer we ordered and just brought a sample tasting of a muscat because he thought I'd like it. Oh, my... be still my wine floozy heart! We had the Lazy Creek gewirtz (excellent), a really yummy merlot/cab sauv/cab franc Cinnabar number out of Santa Cruz and then the aforementioned Alsatian muscat. Someone ordered a bottle of another red that I can't remember the name of and was not so impressed by. We happened to be in the larger "tasting" room on the side with hightop tables and bar chairs. I was jealous of the smaller groups/dates in the cozier entry room as they had couches and cute ottomans. I like to be comfortable when drinking good wine, and find those high tables and chairs a little annoying. But the service was great, value good (we spent about $20 a person and I think most folks got at least 2 good glasses each), parking was SO EASY and while the neighborhood is still working out kinks, I think this is a great way to softly enter into the world of Dogpatch.
author: Holly C.

description: I live in the neighborhood and was soooo looking forward to this place opening up.....but unfortunately I was disappointed each time I went. I love the whole idea of the place, organic wines and stuff and the owner guy (didn't catch his name) is a real sweetheart and very friendly. He built/designed a lot of the place himself. I just didn't like any of the wines I tried at all (I've probably tried 5 or 6) and they weren't cheap (I think about 12-$14 a glass). The chairs (more like ottomans) are not very comfy either. I don't know....I'll give it another try but if I'm going to spend $40 on 2 glasses of wine I want to really enjoy it. Maybe I just haven't been ordering the right thing. I want to support small local businesses and I want this place to succeed so I will go again and give it another shot.
author: lani P.

description:
every time i got to yield i like it more and more... went on wednesday evening and it was more packed & happening than i'd ever seen it.  hurrah!  i love when things pick up at fabulous little gems. 
not only is it a cozy space with such a friendly & knowlegable staff but i actually love that they are on the organic/sustainably farmed bandwagon.  good for you, yield.  
the little flatbreads (= pizzas) are tasty and the cheese options are so super good! 
one of my fave wine bars.  
yay yield!
author: Lija H.

description:
I called Yield the other week to ask if it was OK (read: advise them and hope for a warm welcome) that I was bringing in a group of about 15 college classmates the next evening, which was a Thursday. Although Chris, one of the owners, cautioned me that they didn't take reservations and that I should show up a bit early, I was happily surprised the next evening to find that they had saved us a row of prime window seats. 
My group trickled in over the next 1.5 hours and we stayed quite a while. Our server Duncan was very nice, and although there were a few times when he was slow in checking with new arrivals on their drink desires, he handled us graciously. 
Overall I can't say enough good things about a place where the ever-increasing group (at one point including a well-behaved toddler -- not your standard wine bar patron) was not an issue. Instead of annoyed looks, we received consistently warm service. What a relief! 
The wine list is great, the advice on wine selections is solid, and the food is yummy -- especially the flatbread with mushrooms. 
I will definitely return with a smaller group. It really is a nice place for groups of two to four -- which makes their hospitality even more remarkable.
author: Kate A.

description: Yield is a great place to grab a glass of wine without jeopardizing your hipster image. The interior is shabby, but cool, with interesting art and unique tables (sliced support beams on rollers). There's plenty of fixed-gear parking out front, and if you start feeling like a yuppie, you can get trashed at the saloon next door and wait in line at Just For You the next morning.
author: Tim B.

description: Snobbery without the frustration. Laid back in the Dogpatch, chillin' with the taster trays, which are actually quite superb Hor'dourves. Magnificent!
author: Braden B.

description: One option a wine bar should always have is flights.  I don't understand wine bars that do not.  I love being able to try a few different kinds of wine for the price of about a glass and a half of wine.  I especially love when they have clever names for the flights.  Yield does not have flights, so I was stuck ordering just one glass.  That being said, the glass was really good.  My friend and I shared a flatbread as well, which was also very good.  Loved the atmosphere, and the staff was great.  Definitely need to frequent this neighborhood joint more often.
author: Sarah M.

description: You might think that SF don't need no more stinking wine bars.  But halleluja that it got one.  Spent a few good hours with a few good friends quaffing more than a few great glasses of wine.  Chris, one of the owners, was on site and was extremely helpful with the selections.  Big zins, dainty sav blancs, jumpy rose.  I wasn't disappointed with any of the wines suggested to us (and I tasted about 8 different types that afternoon).  One great reason--another would be Just for You around the corner--to head down to the Dogpatch on a regular basis.
author: Tim L.

description: Great wine bar around the corner from my place.  They serve "organic" wine, so you can feel green about getting buzzed, I guess.  I like the fact that I've enjoyed every wine I've had there over numerous visits.  They also have nice appetizers that are reasonably priced, though they got rid of the foccacia breads sometime towards the end of last year (bummer).  Service is always friendly and informative.  On busy nights, it's super loud and can get warm.
author: Kevin M.

description: Great small bites, excellent selection of unusual wines, comfortable chairs, really friendly and unassuming staff....Yield is a perfect out-of-the-way spot for a low-key hang.  Dig it.
author: Lee S.

description: Good wine. Great atmosphere. Reminds me of Brooklyn in a the best way.
author: Ruth S.

description: Organic and biodynamic wines.  Fantastic flatbreads.  Impeccable service.    Walking/stumbling distance from home.   The combo has resulted in many happy hours turned late nights.  Time does indeed yield here.
author: Jamie W.

description: For the tyramine-addicted in all of us. Excellent wine selection, fine selection of cheeses. Chill atmosphere (without being too subdued), with fire coming out of the wall (or so it seemed in my glazed state of bliss). Not cheap, though, so if your a poor grad student or the like, make your rich date/uncle/mother/ex take you.
author: Stephen H.

description: Organic and biodynamic (definition forgotten after our 3rd bottle of the Cab Franc) wines in a cute cozy place.  Nice to see new places in Dogpatch.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Yield is a nice wine bar in the up-and-coming Dogpatch neighborhood. I thought it was kind of cheesy that when I asked for a recommendation on what specific wine to drink that they pointed at one of the most expensive glasses on the menu, but a lot (if not most) trendy wine bars and restaurants will do that. Plus, it was a great glass of wine so I had 2.
author: Wes F.

description: Comfortable wine bar around the corner from my office.  Solid wine selections, somewhat steep pricing.  Cracker-like pizzas have interesting combinations of ingredients which work some of the time.  Great mod fireplace in the side room.
author: Bibby G.

description:
i heart yield.  i've spent sooo many fabulously quaint evenings here... sipping on wonderful wine and re-connecting with friends.  it is my favorite place to go in the entire bay area.

[and it's true, organic wine hangovers aren't as bad.  so keep 'em coming!]
author: Stitchy M.

description:
what a great place tucked in the dogpatch.  it's nyc style but with a laid back sf attitude.  

if you bring a group of friends, you pretty much take over the whole place.  but the smaller size also gives it some charm.
the flat pizzas(lavosh) are really good.  i gobbled up one and didn't want to share it while i downed their selection of wine.  the group of gals that i was with also ordered the chocolate (we sampled all bits of different flavors) and cheeses.

they have one large bathroom.  ok, i do have my weird ratings on bathrooms but i'm big in cleanliness and privacy.

back to the wine bar, ok the service is super friendly and the staff is too nice.  i had to wait for friends but wanted to get something from the convenience store so one of the guys offered to go for me.  sweet folk.

i wished i lived closer since i'd be there everyday.  

it's a definite stop if you do happen to be in the neighborhood.
author: Anh V.

description: As a wine bar, great place - and cool offbeat location.
author: Jasper M.

description:
My girlfriends and I came here one night not too long after Yield opened. We had a really wonderful time- the particular bottle of wine we wanted was, we were told, potentially corked, so they opened it and let us try it first, just in case; it was corked and they were very cool about letting us pick another bottle and recommending something similar. I love that all the wines are biodynamic, sustainable or organic. The plates are great and include I think all my favorite food things....cheese, fruit and chocolate. Oh, and olives. Really, what more could I want? (Okay, let's not go there right now....)
Pricing is pretty reasonable I think- I've been to less great wine bars with less great wine that charged more. Service- excellent, friendly, helpful, etc., etc. 
The next time we went, we had to wait for a table! Yay I'm glad they are having more business, but it is sad for our girls' nights...we ended up getting a table near the little fireplace which was really nice. Yield has totally become our special little spot and, despite the crowdedness, it's just right.
author: Barbs J.

description: Please make sure to come to a full STOP at Yield. This is the "dive bar" of wine bars...me likey mucho. Met for a few dates here with a guy I was seeing. (The guy? 2 stars) They have an impressive list (tempranillo blanco? Hello Lover!) and are all organic and/or biodynamic. Small, intimate, unpretentious, you should go, like now.
author: D H.

description:
I am not Yield's biggest fan, which is unfortunate, because I would really like to be. It's a cool space with plenty of comfy chairs and ottomans, plus some tall tables in back and a bar. The wine is all organic, sustainable, biodynamic. And the food menu, though really more small bites, has some great picks, including a fantastic cheese plate and this addictive truffle flatbread. And its location in Dogpatch makes it convenient to downtown and the freeway, and means parking is easy.

So why am I not feeling the love for Yield? The noise -- I find it really difficult to have a conversation in there. The price -- I'm not frugal by any means, but I can't seem to wrap my head around spending around $15 a glass. They should really add more decent, mid-priced wines. The staff -- Certainly nice enough, but not really very warm (though I think this is because they're just really busy. But still -- it contributes to the overall, kind of unfriendly vibe I get in here). And, though I admit this is so nitpicky, Yield doesn't allow you to bring in a cake for someone's bday. Let me note that I am only aware of this policy because my friend had her bday gathering there, and they very graciously made an exception for her because she's a regular (though they made it clear that she's an exception). Now, if they specialized in desserts, I would totally get this. But this policy strikes me as just a tad bitchy for the rest of us non-regulars. If allowing a cake means that 10-15 people will show up, order multiple glasses (most likely bottles, even), probably some food, and generally drop a big wad of cash in your establishment, wouldn't you bend that rule?
author: Jen R.

description: This is a great casual spot in a funky neighborhood.  The dogpatch is not as far away as I thought and a cool area, interest loft spaces.  The wine at Yield is well chosen and paired with a rotating selection of cheeses.  The service is a bit too slow, but the people know their wines well and are always kind.  Also a nice date place..
author: Hashem B.

description: My first trip out to Dogpatch (why do they call it that?) was well worth it.  Yield is a really great little place with a good wine selection, friendly service, and cozy atmosphere.  Our waiter (Duncan, I think?) was really knowledgeable and he made some great suggestions - I was really happy with the shiraz and cab he recommended.  We had a couple of cheese plates (damn, I love cheese), and they were good too, except that the brie was too salty.  Easy parking, too.
author: DD B.

description:
I loved this place.  Despite the two obnoxious and rather large parties that were gathering here.  
It's a small but chic little place in the Dogpatch.  There is plenty of parking to be had, which is a godsend in the city.  The colors are soothing and the lighting is rather ambient.  I really liked the art work on the walls.  
I have never seen/had so many organic wines in my life.  The ones that I have tried in the past were just so so.  But I really enjoyed the wines that I tried here at Yield.  I had the pinot noirs, both were good, though I preferred the Mendocino one.  My gf and friend had the grenache blend and the grenacha.  Both were excellent.  
We had a cheese plate that was delicious, a scrumptious flat bread, and some of my favorite chocolates this side of the Mississippi...Poco Dulce in Aztec Chili.  Trust me on the chocolate.  
Later in to the evening, the ladies ordered the bubbly stuff.  Excellent as well.  
We all left with a feeling on love and gratitude towards Yield.  
I am looking forward to another visit soon.
author: jen n.

description:
What IS a dogpatch, anyhow? I didn't see any patches of green OR dogs nearby... 

We wandered in here with plans of just having a glass of wine before heading to a Photography Open Studio that was around the corner, and we were gonna see if they had some nibbles to tide us over for a much later dinner. Well, we certainly didn't need to ASK if they had nibbles, because as soon as you open the door and step into this buzzing yet quiet, cozy, friendly, warm, makes-you-want-to-sink-into-the-low-comfy-sofas-and-take-your-shoes-off room, the aroma of freshly baking flatbreads consumes you, someone greets you and seats you immediately and hands you a wine list and flatbread menu, and next thing you know, you're ordering 2 different types of flatbreads to share (both were delicious), and a glass of wine - and shortly thereafter, ANOTHER glass - and maybe even  another. (note - my friend who normally likes Rose wine tried 2 of their greek rose wines, and didn't really care for either - I guess greek rose is very different than california rose)

REALLY friendly service and everyone else around us also seemed to be enjoying themselves, too, which makes for an even nicer vibe.

All of their wines are organic, and a bonus for vegetarian is that there wasn't any meat or fish on the menu (at least not on the menu we saw last night) - there were even some vegan substitutions available for those who didn't want smoked mozzarella.  And even though I'm a meat eater, I didn't feel like I missed out - I really enjoyed the vegetarian  flatbreads - very tasty, intereseting, and different, and we didn't even need to grab dinner after since they perfectly hit the spot. 

Check it out sometime!
author: beth l.

description: I've been meaning to check out Yield for a while, and when I finally showed up it was late-ish (11) on a Saturday night.  The place was PACKED - my party of three never ended up finding a seat.  Luckily there was a bit of standing room with ledges for your glass - we decided to stick around since we had taken a cab all the way out there.  The service was excellent - very friendly - though we were disappointed that their kitchen was closed (after 10).  They kept us stocked with carafes of water, which was hugely appreciated.  I found myself wishing that they had more wines by the glass, since standing up we were not particularly in the mood to go for an entire bottle.  I certainly plan to return when there's room to stay a while for food and lots more drink.
author: Natalie S.

description: I am not in love with the decor but the wines were spot on.  I had a Zinfandel, an Alexander Valley Pinot Noir, and  Loire Valley Cabernet-France.  Go for the Pinot Noir, it was very tasty.  I know its against their whole green mindset, but I wish they served meat based small dishes.  Easy parking around Potrero, would come back to this place.
author: Marc M.

description:
This is a sweet spot for wine lovers in SF. Yes it's the 'boonies' of SF, but it's still the city! 

The owner is looks quite young but imports a crazy selection of wine. Sometimes he even has wines from China and Japan. I happen to go with a friend who was a regular there and knew the owner so we had a chance to sample a bit. But that may be one of those things where you have to know the owner to try. 

There's not a huge selection of appetizers, but their chocolate sampler is pretty darn good. (Yes, that's an appetizer too!) Reasonably priced glasses of wine, and again, fab selection.1
author: Annie T.

description:
i am giving them three stars because it is in my neighborhood, and i give them kudos for opening something up on 3rd street, which is still a bit of a gamble. the wine list was pretty good, and the service was good, but i have a few complaints. first in the back area they have elementary school industrial stools to sit on..a total disconnect with the dark designed interior, they had this really cool unit mounted to the wall with flames coming out and then we are sitting on the most uncomfortable cheapest stools in the world!! my back was killing me, i don't care how good your wine is, please spend some money on some proper seating!!

i also have a huge problem with cheese plates that are miniscule, if you are goin to charge $7 for petite robert brie cheese plate(how is it a plate if it is one sliver of cheese i ask you?), which you can buy at trader joes for $6 for a whole wheel, then please give us more than 1 oz., it wasn't just dissappointing, it was laughable.

anyway, the long and short of it is....i will be back, its three blocks from my house! and i really appreciate having it here, but i don't know if it would survive long in any other hood, where the people aren't as desperate as we are.
author: Kai H.

description: Really enjoyed this place. Nice selection of wine, smaller venue great for just catching up w/a friend or two over a drink. Some great bites to nosh on too. Friendly staff and very chill casual approachable ambiance when I went.
author: Abby W.

description: Trivia Night is the best! Haven't tasted the food yet but I'm sure I will one day.
author: Elizabeth A.

description: I FINALLY made it to Yield. Now I'm not sure how I'm going to stay away. Given that its a few blocks from my house, has a great wine selection, the couple running the place are so kind and friendly, it's small, intimate, decorated well. Its so damn comfy. I felt like I could have sat there all night. I'll be here on a weekly basis - I mean drinking alone in a great comfy wine bar next door isn't the same as drinking at home alone right? :)
author: melissa g.

description: Service was good and the selection is interesting. Although I love organic foods, I'm going to steer clear of organic wines because they taste yucky! Ok... yucky is too strong .. "lackluster..."
author: Lily C.

description:
with all the new wine bars opening up around the city i just had to write in about this place. great great wines.  it's where i discovered that organic wines seem to taste better.  you should have to be convinced, because not everything's better simply because it's organic.  and i can't vouch for any organic wine. but the ones on their list (which changes a bit too frequently for my taste - but not sure if that's a supply issue) are really good.  

a bit pricey, but well worth it for a quality glass. the bites are good too, but more pricey on the price to quality to quantity ratio, so you're better off spending those extra dollars on more wine instead and getting some cheap fried catfish and corn bread at the hard knox later down the street. 

this one pourer Duncan was really awesome, not sure if he's there anymore, but check this place out for a really good glass (or four!!) of reds.  seriously they make it that easy.

wait, the minus star is half for your hours, please open later so that the next time i roll up a quarter to midnight craving your delicious petite syrah, and your luscious zin, i'm not disappointed.  And the other half minus star is for the bathroom with the large door opening up right into the side room. at least take that big blue industrial toilet sign off the door.
author: Nikki F.

description: Definitely a destination spot. Decor was simple but classy and the wine list was creative and decently priced. I was feeling adventurous so I sampled a glass of the '99 Ct/Merlot from France just because I liked the description: "inky, vanilla, barnyard." It smelled like barnyard, tasted like vanilla and looked inky so the description was right on. Other than the colorful menu, I also thought that the carafe d'eau given to each table was a nice touch and the friendly and efficient service was the cherry on top of the whole experience. The blue-flame fireplace was pretty cool, too.
author: Natalie T.

description: When in San Francisco, do as the San Franciscans do. Biodegradable, Biodiverse, Affirmative Action Grapes of Wrath with Organic Bioflavinoids and all cases of wine are delivered in a bioethanol-solar-wind-bicycle-critical mass-powered rocket, sponsored by Google and O'Reilly Media, operated by Linux and driven by a local lesbian subsistence farmer who wears a sexy biohazard suit (Natashka's favorite part), who listens to Ira Glass and M.I.A. while she presses the grapes, and donates all her profits to an NGO whose mission is to teach children-- born with no internet access (in an underpriveleged country that doesnt recycle their glass wine bottles) -- how to grow organic biodegradable wine grapes, and thus ROCK ON in a more healthy, sustainable, and ethically inebriated third world.
author: natashka o.

description:
this place screamed of gentrification in the dogpatch, but i went anyway to hang out with some friends. 

our sommelier possessed a brand of hippy-hipster-ness that i didn't mind.

i was happy to have discovered my first tempranillo.

the solid chunks of stained wood on casters that were the tables - those were fun. 

the rosemary-laced nuts that went with our cheese plate were a pleasant herbal surprise. 

i had such a good time that it made me want to be less jaded.
author: Winter R.

description: Yield was a great local feeling place to have a great glass (bottle) of wine!  I enjoyed the ambiance of this smaller wine bar with helpful staff and tasty cheese plate.  I plan on going back soon...
author: sheldon r.

description: Chris had an excellent selection of wines, and was informative about each.  The flatbread was amazing with rock salt and dates on top.  I can't quite figure out why Spike's marinated olives are so good either, but there's some sorta spice that rocked my world.  Fun sitting out on the sidewalk too.  Thumbs up, Yield!
author: Jackie B.

description: Ahh Yield. What can I say about the best little neighborhood wine bar. I stumbled upon yield one day on my walk home and what a gem I stumbled upon. I've been coming here ever since they opened and the place just keeps getting better and better. The service is fantastic - Garrett even remembers me everytime I'm in there (and no, I'm not an alcoholic and in there everyday from the time it opens until the time it closes, if I was I'd just go to the DogPatch Saloon). Anyway, I have not had a wine there that I did not like. I don't even have to order anymore - the recommendations are always spot on. Oh, and it helps that it is within walking distance from home, so I can just stumble home.
author: melissa t.

description:
what a great lil spot. one of the best things about it is that it's in a relatively quiet hood so it doesn't seem like it ever gets crowded.  i would give 5 stars because the wine, food and service were all incredibly top notch. but i'm docking one for decor. i'm sorry, i just gotta. but let's focus on the top-notches, shall we?

had two glasses of the tempranillo--and it was delicious. the very nice bartender let me taste a couple other reds too--a seriously strong merlot from australia and a light syrah/mourvedre from france, which showed great range in their red selections. but i decided to stick with the tempranillo. we also ordered a couple of the best flatbreads i have ever had. my favorite was the mushroom, chard, cashew creme and truffle oil. decadent, meaty, and full of flavor. 

love the organic wine idea and i think they've done a great job with the wine list. the only thing i would do is amp up the decor a little. they need some vibrant artwork or some interesting chairs thrown in to give the room more interest. we had a great time chatting with the bartender and will definitely be back.
author: rachel p.

description: Yield Wine Bar is a nice departure from the San Francisco usual suspects of overly pretentious wine bars.  I like that Yield had a nice offering, has a great philosopy and is in touch with being a place to come as you are.  I do get annoyed with the uncomfortable, overly crowded, too noisy, poor service, and un-thoughtful wine list.  Yield's principal created this space and completed the work themselves.  The service is down-to-earth and make the wine experience more approachable.   The neighbourhood needed such a good establishment.  The only thing I would add would be fortified / dessert  wines.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Great bar with a varied selection of wines to choose from. Like most wine bars, it has clean, modern decor; flattering candlelight; and great waitstaff. Can't wait to go back!
author: Richie K.

description:
great cozy ambiance and plush chairs. service is knowledgeable and friendly.

minus one star each for running out of flat bread and giving me expired beer.....good thing I didn't get a tummy ache.
author: Katie K.

description: Great spot . . great wine. Its still gaining momentum but is really a wonderful place to meet up with friends for a bottle (or 2) of wine. Good vibe . . . good people.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
cute stylee unassuming wine bar in the DP. 
we likes.
author: Caroline S.

description: A cute, unexpected place in this area - I love that it is so close to my work at Mission Bay and I dont have to travel into downtown for happy hour.   The black olive mushroom tart with truffle oil is yum...
author: Amina B.

description:
took my ladyfriend here for a nice evening of wine and snackypoos. unfortunately, it was open till 11 but the food part shut down at 10, so we had to drink only, which was disappointing but understandable. they have organic/biodynamic wine, which makes them the first "green" wine bar in SF-- i'm surprised that it's taken this long to fill that niche. 

i love organic food. love it. and i surprisingly had not yet found a tasty organic wine, so i was hoping yield would show me otherwise on that regard. and they did. i wish i could remember which ones i tried, but alas i cannot. but i did recall that not enough wines were offered by the glass--at a wine bar, don't you want to have many things offered by the glass or even by 2 oz. pours so you can try many things? isn't that the point? also, they didn't really have flights, at least not on the menu. 

but i really liked this place. cozy interior decor, not little two-person cocktail tables but lots of group-style benches. right on the new T street light rail line, so this bar is a harbinger of things to come for the dogpatch. go there before it's crowded and everyone's talking about it.
author: Marla W.

description: Went here for happy hour on a Friday.  Really great and unique rotating wine menu.  I want to hunt down that white wine from Greece they had that tasted almost exactly like apple juice.  Their flats are great too.  This place gets pretty crowded though and is on the small side.  The staff are very friendly about giving you recommendations.
author: Jean A.

description: We met some friends here for a quick drink before going to the Potrero Theatre - it was fantastic - good service and very relaxed atmosphere.   Nice to finally have a good wine bar in Potrero.
author: Gina C.

description: This place is quaint, with a good wine selection and a staff that makes you feel like you are just hanging out at a friends house.
author: Jerry S.

description: I'm a fan of small, intimate spaces. Yield is perfect for one-on-one time as the two of you sink into their dark leather couches.  I much prefer that to sitting at the bar or in the tables in the back.  The wine selection is nice, all the cheese are lovely and parking is so, so easy.
author: Kimmie N.

description: Yield was a stopping point, as I had a reservation at Serpentine across the street.  It was my first time and I will definitely be back.   The wine selection is varied enough and all or organic or biodynamic (although all are not certified.)  I had the muscadet and lentil spread on crostini app and both were terrific.
author: Krista B.

description: My husband and I love, love, love this place and we're not biased because we know the owners Chris and Jennifer but because the place has a great vibe,  awesome selection of wines and some tasty tapas dishes.  We've been several times and have taken our foodie/wine loving friends and always have a wonderful time.
author: Jeanne F.

description: Great find, a friend of mine suggested this place and I most say it was a great find, the wine selection is accompanied by a wonderful description, the ambiance is cozy and warm.  you can sit on the sofas, the bar or at a table.  The host/owner is friendly, knowledgeable and always ready to give advice if you cant decide what to have.  Oh yes, they now have tasty dishes to accompany your wine.  Way thumbs up.
author: Emmy B.

description: Lovely wines and really helpful service.  On the food menu, they have taken away things I loved -- like those delicious flatbreads they had when they first opened -- but they've replaced them with other very yummy items.
author: Annette K.

description: This is a great wine bar with an atmosphere that makes you want to get comfortable and stay for hours. Every wine I have tried has been fabulous, and I can't wait to work my way through the rest of the list. One of the owners, Chris, is happy to guide people through the selection and help choose a glass or bottle that will be just right. This is the best wine bar I have found yet in San Francisco, by far the most comfortable and appealing of all of them. Anyone in search of a cozy wine bar should try it out, and I guarantee you'll be going back.
author: Rosemary D.

description: This is the perfect place to spend a nice chill evening with some friends.  It has a really laid back atmosphere.  The decor is really casual and the service staff is really friendly.  The wines are really good.  Lots of good food to choose from.  Can't ask for more!
author: Sam C.

description: Great little spot with a nice selection of organic wines - and an extremely tasty small menu as well. Definitely a good addition to an industrial yet definitely developing neighborhood.
author: Kate T.

description: If you love wine, this place is definitely for you.  I'm only a fair weather fan of wine so I'm probably not the best person to ask.  The food was pretty decent too.  I loved the cheese.  Yeah, I'm lactose intolerant, but who cares -- well I guess the people I went with cared.
author: Ming L.

description: Some really good wines, and in the reasonably priced range.  Really good food to go with the wine.   And despite the best efforts of some of my friends who had a bit too much wine, I may even be able to go back there again.
author: Alured P.

description:
This is really more of a 3 1/2 star place in my opinion.  Went here awhile ago and forgot to throw in my 2 nickels on the experience.  It was a Saturday and moderately busy around 7:30.  Friendly staff and decent wine (not that it was all that memorable).  

The problem I have about this place is the lack of atmosphere.  The space is not laid out well and the crowd seemed to come and go in huge waves - one moment it's packed, another it's darn near empty (did I mention it was a Saturday night at peak bar hours?)

So unless I am meeting people there, I probably won't make the trek out.  Afterall, the District is literally a hop and stumble away from home.
author: Ames C.

description: What a find! Very low key (seated right away, at 7:30p on a Thursday night), great wine selection, especially with its emphasis on organic and sustainably raised grapes (we didn't try any of the food), comfy and well-designed space. They missed five stars only because our server didn't seem that interested in discussing wines/offering suggestions, but the service was otherwise excellent (prompt, attentive, etc.). Will absolutely go there again with friends. Also kind of romantic, so good for date night. :)
author: Arkay K.

description: Yield is a sweet little spot for a date or a get-together with girlfriends. Wines are $9-$15 per glass, with a good mix of red, white, sparking, and dessert. I had a tempranillo ($10 and delicious), my friend had a muscat ($9, I think), and my other girlfriend had a $3 sliver of coconut almond chocolate. Wait staff is very friendly and ambiance is cozy. Bonus points for easy parking and accessibility to CalTrain and the T-Third.
author: Paige S.

description: Awesome wine bar - all 'green' wines and yummy bites.  The service is knowledgeable and attentive.  I'm still thinking about the poached peaches - get it while you can as the menus change often!
author: Julie C.

description: Cozy, unpretentious wine bar. Not overly crowded, friendly folks, and most of all great wine. Sometimes there is a little Aussie Cattle Dog that hangs out here, too. I'm not sure if it's such a great place for singles to mingle, but for a date it's ideal!
author: S. N.

description: Great Wine.  Great Food. Friendly Staff.  Mad props for opening on 3rd street, not quite the cultural mecca of SF... yet.
author: Alex D.

description: Probably my second favorite wine bar in the city. My poor liver.  In any case, I guess one can justify drinking a half...or maybe a little more...bottle of yummy red wine since what they serve is mostly organic, bio-friendly etc.  The atmosphere is nice here, too. I like this place almost as much as Hotel Biron.  Only two complaints. One, they close on the early side (12pm, at least during the week- not sure about wknds). Two, they told us, upon our 10pm arrival, that we could no longer order cheese because the kitchen was closed. Come on, how much effort does it take to slap a slab of cheese on a plate? Overall, a great new wine bar in a somewhat unlikely part of the city.
author: SL N.

description: An interesting place...the staff and owner were very nice and helpful.  Had a pleasant time.  Location is out-there but its not too bad.  The main room has a nice feel to it but the side room not so much.  It does have a good feel to hangout with some friends.  Don't expect to much...go with some good/fun friends to this place...
author: Temoor N.

description: My husband and I love this place...great place for pre-drinks before heading out to dinner.
author: NYCS F.

description: Just went to Yield and it's a great place for yaking and sipping.  I was  disappointed that they didn't have the wine we selected, but the wait staff was really-really-nice about making another suggestion and at the price of the first wine we wanted to try.  It was a little chilly in there -- big windows and one on top was open, so dress warmly.  though you could sit by the cozy wall fireplace-- I never walked up to it so i wasn't sure it was a video of fire or a real flame going on there.  The staff know their wines-- a very knowledge bunch of cuties.  SUPPORT Yield-- This place rocks!
author: Princess P.

description: I love yield.  Helps that it is just a few blocks from my house - but I still love it.  Its a cool, chic little place.  The wine is great and the two owners are super helpful, nice, knowledgeable.  There is some space for groups.  And the food was delicious too!  Amazing flatbread and chocolate plate.  I had a great time and will be back there soon, and many times in the future I hope!  Makes me love the hill even more than I already did.
author: Emily d.

description: Okay so this place superseded my expectations. I expected to come here and have a couple tapas and a glass of wine and call it a night.  Went there last night (Tuesday) and it was amazing!  They had 3 flamingo dancers, a guitarist and a singer.  The tapas were delicious.  Highly recommended the goat cheese stuffed dates, artichoke spinach dip and polenta cake with mushrooms.  The only bummer was when I wanted to order more spinach dip they were all out.  It was packed last night and the crowd was very down to earth.  Wide age range so anyone will fit in.  The Malbec/Cab Franc was the best red out of the 2 I tried.  Very chill atmosphere and really nice vibe from the people and band.  2 Thumbs Up!
author: Nina S.

description: While I was possibly one of the first people to step inside their doors when they opend last August, I certainly am not the first to write about it, and quite enthusicatically at that! Chris, the owner, is a wonderful host and purveyor of a well-rounded list of biodynamic, organic or sutainable wines. Friendly, approachable and extremely knowledgable, he'll make certain the wine you select is to your taste. Wonderful selection by the glass, good snacking foods and a relaxed, chill atmosphere (nice addition of the "in-wall" fireplace!) with an always-interesting music selection make this the perfect place to kick back with friends, or make new ones.
author: m g.

description:
This is a super cozy little wine bar in the Dogpatch.  Some of the other places that call themselves "wine bars" in San Francisco bridge between cheesy and uptight, but this place doesn't.  It's much more in the tradition of NY and small European places that I've been to.  The decor and artwork are really cool and inviting.  A great place to relax with a friend, a glass of wine and the yummy cheese plate.  The wine list is pretty small, but so far the wines that I've tried have been really good and diverse enough to compensate the smallish list.  I highly recommend it to anyone who likes wine.  

UPDATE:  I had not been back for some time, and recently discovered that they have a new fireplace contraption, which really warms up the smaller room.
author: Buckeye W.

description: ...gazing out the window at the beautiful brick building across the street in the fading Friday afternoon sunlight, sipping rose and munching on manchego with my hot husband. Outstanding selection of obscure wine, delicious reds. Perfect spot to sit for a spell and soak in the neighborhood lovingly referred to as Dogpatch. Woof!
author: Jennifer C.

description: "Hear that sound, Mr Anderson?  That's the sound of inevitability"  The Dogpatch District is starting to yelp.  Once again I"m walking down Third St to go to Renos Liquour for my 2 dollar out the door forty. The little storefront that's had newspapers on the windows as they remodel had literally opened their doors thirty seconds before I walked by.  Right next door to the Dogpatch Saloon.  Just like the Retox right down the street, this is another drinking establishment opened by young first time bar owners.  Not a full bar but a wine bar with the all the bottles standing proud on thick roughhewn shelves.  The front room has assorted seating, the room next to it features tallish tables and stools.  The didn't even have a chance to open their first bottle of wine yet by the time I walked in.  Later on they're hoping to do some food as well.  The atmosphere is definite homespuny but let's give them a bit of time and I'll see how they have it together in the next few days..
author: paul k.

description: I really digged Yield. I've been there a few times now. I've now sampled from every part of the menu. The red wines on the menu run the gambit of the red spectrum, "big reds" through ports. They've have got a really good Australian red, I don't recall the name of. The Whites are also really tasty, with one of Guvertz being my favorite. A real good ensemble of organic, sustainable wines. The menu is up to par with cheese and fruit selections that are good nibblers while talking with friends and sipping good wine.  The space is inviting with the comfy leather chairs beckoning you from the street. I do like the art in the rooms as it matches the ambiance of the street however, I would like to see some local art (perhaps in the future?) Also, Chris is a really awesome guy who will help you navigate the wine selection for that spot-on wine. Bottom-line: Need to unwind from the anarchy, relax and unwind with a glass of wine at Yield!
author: Joseph S.

description: Good wine in a totally unpretentious setting...with couches? Love it. The clientele is a bit bourgeois/ladies who lunch for my liking...so if you're not those things start packing the place and it will be a slam dunk.
author: Lester D.

description: I have lived within 6 blocks of Yield for a couple years now (on and off) and I am ashamed... ASHAMED! that this past Friday night was my first foray inside. My girlfriend and I wanted to check it out, and we showed up around 8pm and were instantly in love. The decor is great. The 3 guys working (Nick, Duncan and Kevin... see, they made an impression!) were the sweetest most awesome guys. They made us both feel like fast friends, suggesting fantastic wines, and cooking us AMAZING small-plate food. What an awesome time we had, and the prices on everything (most notably the food, given the quality... good show, Kevin!) were extremely reasonable. My only hope (but I have little doubt) is that the owner is as cool and "into it" as the three guys working there. The wines were fantastic, the food was brilliant, and the service... well... to be fair it didn't even feel like 'service'. It felt like friends or family having you over for wine and food.
author: B S.

description: went here last night with a group of friends and it was great. highly recommend the black chairs - which shall always be referred to as the "comfy" chairs. so comfy. the wines are all organic and i had a nice glass of sicilian wine . lots of choices. the bartender is the owner and he's super chill and not a pretentious wine snob. great mellow place. a bit out of my way, but worth it.
author: T O.

description: Yield is a solid little wine bar. Totally laid back. Usually mellow.  you'll be able to find parking and a seat.  Service is friendly - not super swanky or slick.  Wine is pretty good and they have a few nibbles.
author: Fallon C.

description: It's not my neighborhood, but Yield is a great neighborhood spot to grab a glass of wine, have a small bite, and catch-up with friends.  The staff strikes the perfect balance - they are there when you need something and are witty, funny and friendly when answering questions about wines, but give you space and time to enjoy it all - no rushing here.
